MEMORANDUM

re

SCHOOL BUILDING

for

BELLA BELLA

BELLA COOLA AGENCY, B.C.

by

A. UNSWORTH

C.E. Webb, Esq.,
District Chief Engineer,
Vancouver, B.C.

Bella Bella, B.C.
September 1, 1947.
MEMORANDUM

Re: War Assets Building for Bella Bella School Site,
Bella Coola Agency, British Columbia.

October 14, 1947.

With reference to your notation of August 6th last on Mr. Hoey's memorandum to you dated August 2nd regarding the removal of Building No. 5 in connection with the school site we wrote to Mr. C.S. Webb of our Vancouver office asking him to review the matter with the Indian Commissioner and to arrange for a member of his staff to investigate conditions at the site and to submit a report to this office covering the project as soon as possible.

We have now received from Mr. Webb, a Report by Mr. A. Unsworth of his staff, dated September 1st which is self explanatory, together with a sketch plan of the building, and two copies of each are transmitted to you herewith.

You will note that Mr. Unsworth recommends taking the building completely apart as the only practical method of removal, and suggests salvaging and reusing the material in a building of standard plan.

We concur in his recommendation against moving the building as a whole or in sections to the Bella Bella Indian Day School Site, and it would appear questionable whether, if the building were demolished and the material salvaged, much of such material could be economically utilized in a standard building.

Copies of Mr. Unsworth's report have been forwarded to the Indian Commissioner for his information.

The further information referred to by Mr. Unsworth has not been received in this office. We are writing to Mr. Webb and will advise you as soon as we hear further from him on the subject.

Enclos.

J.M. Wardle, Esq.,
Director,
Surveys and Engineering Branch,
Department of Mines and Resources,
OTTAWA, Ont.

Chief Engineer.

Memorandum to Mr. Webb:

Re: School Building for Bella Bella
Supplement to Memorandum, September 1, 1947.

As mentioned in previous memorandum the amount of care exercised in dismantling a building will determine the amount of good material available. The enclosed sheets are an estimate on material available, the estimated cost of dismantling and delivery to school site, and estimated value of material at school site.

The estimated cost of salvage and delivery, ($1120.00), does not cover the replacement of 320 feet of roadway from main road to school grounds in the Indian Village.

It will be necessary to hire and bring in a 2½-ton lumber truck, either from Vancouver or perhaps Bella Coola. It is also necessary to hire a scow and tow boat, probably from the British Columbia Packers at Namu. These items will be of considerable expense, but should be covered by the $1120.00.

If white men are brought in some costs should be added for fares and subsistence.

The present school is supplied with electric lighting only from the R.W. Large Memorial Hospital, 115 Volt D.C. plant. The capacity of this plant will not permit further expansion from this source. It would appear that the hospital authorities have in mind the installing of a larger A.C. unit but have insufficient funds to do so. The hospital supply is the best for school use as it is a 24-hour service. The village plant

Indian Affairs. (RG 10, Volume 6385, File 802-5, part 3)

PUBLIC ARCHIVES ARCHIVES PUBLIQUES CANADA
only runs in the evenings during the winter months. There is no justification in running the village plant through the day, but the continual cloudy weather makes it necessary to have the school rooms lighted during most of the school term. A small plant would be a means of supplying power, but would require some attention which may not be possible from the teaching staff. Therefore, it would appear that some agreement with the hospital authorities in respect to new equipment in that institution would result in the most satisfactory lighting supply for the school.

It would appear that the removal of a building from Air Base to the Indian village is not very profitable if any purchase price is involved. However, if one building is removed it may be considered reasonable to remove others to make up sufficient material for a school. Therefore mention is now made of Building 4 which is fundamentally a duplication of Building 5, with partition rooms added, and would yield about the same amount of material.

There is also Building 40, a prefabricated type, which would yield some 150 whole panels of 4'x9'6"-1/2" fir 3-ply, plus much of the same material about 2'x9'6". These panels have been layed with few nails on walls of rooms. The siding of building 40 is of tongue and groove material 1-5/8" thick, 4/8" face, of cedar equivalent to No. 1 common fir (there are some tight knots in it).

This material is toe-nailed very lightly from the inside to 2"x3" studding.
The salvage from this siding would be high with comparably little labour. The roof and floor of this building are of no salvage value, except the floor joists of 2" x 8". Further data have been collected and can be submitted if of interest. The size of building is about 24' x 120', and has five water closets, 10 wash basins, and 2 oil furnaces with circulating fans, all in good condition.

A. Unsworth.

APPROVED

MEMORANDUM

Re: War Assets Building for
Belle Bella School Site,
Bella Coola Agency, B.C.

With reference to our memorandum of October 14th last, in connection with the above, we have since received from Mr. C.F. Webb, Dominion Water & Power Bureau, 744 Hastings Street West, Pacific Building, Vancouver, a supplementary memorandum with a detailed estimate of salvage costs of No. 5 building, prepared by Mr. A. Unsworth of his staff. The memorandum is self explanatory and duplicate copies are transmitted herewith for the information of the Indian Affairs Branch.

You will note from previous correspondence that the building referred to is located at the Denny Island, R.C.A.F., Sea Plane Base at Bella Bella and that we were advised that Indian Affairs had arranged to purchase and remove it across an inlet to the site of the present Indian Day School for use as additional class rooms and teacherages.

Mr. Unsworth estimates the present salvage value of the material in the building as it stands, at about $1400.00 and the cost of dismantling the building and removing the materials to the new site by Indian labour at $1120.00

If, however, white men have to be employed to operate a lumber truck, saw and tow boat which it would be necessary to hire, additional costs would be involved that would probably make the cost of salvaging at least equal to the value of similar new materials.

As previously stated, it is doubtful whether any large proportion of salvaged material could be utilized to advantage in the construction of a new standard building. Also the degree of care exercised in dismantling the building and the condition of the salvaged material are factors which would of course affect its value. The question of the procurability of new materials and the suitability of that salvaged, are matters upon which we cannot advise at this distance.

It would appear from Mr. Unsworth's list, that the material most likely to be worth while salvaging short of dismantling the whole building, are the window sash and doors, plumbing fixtures and some piping, heating equipment and electrical lighting fixtures and wiring. The estimated cost of removal and delivery of the above named materials, including the amount for contingencies are given at about $191.00 and its value at the school site at $475.00.

Copies of Mr. Unsworth's memorandum were forwarded to Indian Commissioner MacKay of Vancouver by Mr. Webb at an earlier date.

Enclosure

R.A. Gibson, Esq.,
Director,
Lands and Development Services Branch,
Department of Mines and Resources,
Ottawa, Ontario.

Indian Affairs. (RG 10, Volume 6385, File 802-5, part 3)
With reference to the pre-fabricated building No. 40 mentioned by Mr. Unsworth, Mr. Webb states that - "If of lighter construction it might be knocked down and reconstructed as teachers residence or as a two room school. Actually in an 80 ft. long building there are just enough windows to provide for two 42 ft. by 24 ft. class rooms and with wastage there would not be enough material to also build a two teacher residence. It would, however, be possible to build a combined one room school and two teacher residence. However, before making a recommendation in this connection I would require to discuss it further with Mr. Unsworth who has seen the building in question".

Chief Engineer.
December 30, 1947.

Major D.M. MacKay, Indian Commissioner,
P.O. Box 70, Vancouver, B.C.

We have your letter of the 24th instant, file 2-11-1, in which you state that after conferring with the officers of the Lands and Development Services Branch in Vancouver it has been decided to leave the question of an addition to the Bella Bella School in abeyance until the cost of transferring the buildings is determined.

As you know, we have already purchased building No. 5 at the R.C.A.F. Seaplane base, Benny Island - see your voucher 133 of August 28, 1947.

Bernard F. Neary
Supt. of Welfare & Training.

PP/MGD
Indian Affairs Branch, Dept. of Mines and Resources,
Ottawa, Ont.

Re: Bella Bella School Addition
Your File 182-3-5 W.T.1

With reference to Mr. Neary's letter of December 19th and reports by the Lands and Development Services Branch regarding the proposed removal of the building from the Bella Bella Air Base as an addition to the above mentioned school, the information provided indicates that the proposal would probably not be economical.

I have discussed this matter recently with the local office of the Lands and Development Services Branch who are presently moving buildings from the Port Hardy Military Camp to Campbell River and Cape Mudge by freighter, and feel that it would be advisable to leave the question of an addition to the Bella Bella school in abeyance until the cost of transferring buildings from Port Hardy by freighter is determined. A copy of my letter of December 11th to R.C.T. Webb in this connection is enclosed for your information.

D. W. MacKay,
Indian Commissioner for B.C.
Dec. 11, 1947.

C. H. Webb, Esq., District Chief Engineer, Dominion Water and Power Bureau, Vancouver, B.C.

I am enclosing a copy of Mr. Indian Agent Pruden's letter of November 26th in connection with building requirements at Bella Bella for day school use.

In your letter of October 23rd you advised that the proposed use of one of the buildings from the Bella Bella Air Base would be the subject of a further recommendation following discussion of the matter with Mr. Unsworth but I now understand from my recent discussion with Col. Whyte that it might be feasible and more economical to transfer buildings from Port Hardy by freighter and that you will be in a position to advise definitely regarding this point at a later date when costs of transferring buildings to Campbell River in this manner have been determined.

I am also enclosing a letter dated November 15th from Mr. Pruden regarding the transfer of another building from the Bella Bella Air Base to Klemtu for school use. It is understood that this proposal also will be given consideration in the light of information secured regarding transfer of buildings from Port Hardy to Campbell River.

Ottawa, December 19, 1947.

Major D.M. MacKay, Indian Commissioner,
P.O. Box 70, Vancouver, B.C.

Enclosed for your information is a copy of a memorandum just received from the Chief Engineer of the Lands and Development Services Branch. He attached to his memorandum a report from Engineer Unsworth in connection with the proposed removal of a building to Bella Bella as an addition to the school.

We understand that you have already received a copy of Mr. Unsworth's report.

Please let me have your comments on the information submitted by Mr. Unsworth and you might also state if the expenditure required to dismantle and remove the buildings to the new site can be paid from the amount already allotted for construction of new school buildings in British Columbia during the current fiscal year.

Bernard F. Neary
Supt. of Welfare & Training.

Ottawa, December 12, 1947.

Mr. Hoey:

Re: War Assets Building for Bella Bella School Site, Bella Coola Agency, B.C.

I am attaching a copy of Chief Engineer Mill's memorandum of the 9th instant with reference to a previous memorandum of October 14th and accompanying report by Engineer Unsworth of September 1st which has just been supplied to us along with Mr. Wardle's file in regard to the Agency under discussion.

No doubt you will have heard from Mr. Mackay by this time and in view of the information we are now supplying, we would like to have your further views before any action is taken by the Engineering and Construction Division.

R. A. Gibson,

Dear Sir,

In answer to yours received by last mail I would say that I am quite satisfied with my position as teacher at Bella Coola Indian School. I cannot honestly say, however, that I like the work with the present accommodation. When I first accepted this school (three years come June) the Indian agent promised a new building. Then Mr. Lorenz - the late agent - visited us, and said he would lay the urgency of the need before the Government. Mr. Green - Inspector for British Columbia - also assured us that we would have a new school house as soon as possible. But there has been no official word of commencing work.
on one as yet. Last year we built a very nice church, but as we fully expected that school accommodation would be provided, we made no provision for the children. For many reasons it is impossible to hold sessions in the church, so we are using a small room at the rear which was erected as a small class room. It is 12' x 14' and only about 7'6" high. The light is very poor as the windows are small and placed very high. The desks are placed against this wall and at times, in fact as a general thing, the children, especially those sitting at the rear of the room, cannot see the blackboard at all. I find it utterly impossible to give proper instruction as the little ones have to sit three and four in an ordinary school desk and I cannot reach the inside ones at all. There is no ventilation at all except
by doors, there are no cupboards whatever,
and the blackboard space is very
small. These, and many more
inconveniences, make the work
very hard and most discouraging.
The children here are increasing
in numbers and are a strong
healthy lot. I would like to see
a thoroughly equipped school in
Bella Coola for I know it would be
taken advantage of by many who
do not at present attend and the
value of the work would be
increased one hundred fold.

As regards the salary, I may say
that I think it is not in proportion
with the work. The poorest paid
public school teacher receives $600
a year, and by experience fits herself
for a higher position. An Indian
school unfit one for an advanced
position and not only that, but even
with the greatest care, any education
previously gained by the teacher, is
One has to simplify everything to the last degree in order to be understood, as the children cannot understand any English when first entering school. The position looks easy, but I believe it is one of the most trying in the world; the sameness of it all—the drilling to get one single idea into their heads and the very simplicity of everything decreases the teacher's intellectual value. For this reason I think the salary should be increased. I had notice from our Indian agent last August that I was to receive $6-00 instead of $400. But the chairman of this District has had no word of such an increase, so it remains as before—$400.

Yes, I am quite willing to accept the position for the coming year and will do my best with the children. I do hope that a new school will be provided, however.
Trusting I have not written at too great length,
with kind regards
I remain
Yours truly,

Referring to your letter of May 24 received last week, after an absence from the office of six weeks, I have the honor to state that the teacher has been notified of the closing of the day school at Bella Coola owing to poor attendance. She had previously received notice, presumably through Mr. Ferrier, Superintendent of Indian Schools, Methodist Church.

Personally I have often urged the parents to send the children to school more regularly, and they have promised to do so; but added that the children do not learn anything at school. As in other coast villages the parents take the children with them when they go away handlogging, or to the canneries. Last winter the influenza was followed at Bella Coola by the whooping cough; this of course reduced the attendance to a minimum.

Viewing the declaration made by the parents at Bella Coola in the letter to Mr. Ferrier, copy of which is enclosed herewith, I most respectfully ask that the natives be given another chance of proving their interest in the education of their children, and that this school be re-opened on October 1st, this year. It would also be important that Mr. Ferrier recommends a teacher in whom the natives have confidence, if there is to be a choice of teacher.

Special Report in accordance with Departmental Letter 4-210 dated January 14, 1931, and attached to my Report on the Bella Coola Indian Day School

In accordance with the instructions issued to me by the Department of Indian Affairs, I am forwarding this special report for your information:

I beg to state that I do not consider the services of Mrs. Isabella Snodgrass, at present teacher of the Indian Day School at Bella Coola, to be satisfactory. I have therefore to request that she be removed from her position as teacher of this school. My reasons for making this special report and recommendation are that, as you will see from my report on the Bella Coola Indian Day School, the teaching is not satisfactory, the progress of the children most unsatisfactory, and the health of the teacher a very doubtful quantity.

Below will be found a copy of a letter from the teacher in which she requests me to cancel her application for a transfer, and in which she admits that even to herself the progress of the children is unsatisfactory.

Copy:-

Dear Captain Barry,

By this letter I wish to cancel my application for a change of school. A suitable change would be pretty hard to find for me. I have been worried over what you think of the school. The progress is not at all satisfactory to myself. But I worked hard & faithfully & did a lot which is not seen.

At first I felt like resigning but I'm young yet, only 48, and surely with the facilities now available I can do as well as any other teacher. I'll do my best.

Yours faithfully,
Isabel Snodgrass.

I do not consider that Mrs Snodgrass will make a success of teaching in an Indian Day School. When inspecting at Bella Coola I advised her to try to get an appointment in an Indian Residential School if she could hear of an opening. She might be able to supervise the laundry or kitchens. She is certainly not fit enough in my opinion to teach school at Bella Coola, and to visit around the Indian homes to look after the interests of the children. She admits to heart disease and lameness.

If it is not considered that the above are sufficient grounds for a change of teacher, I shall be very glad indeed; but from a professional point of view I have no other course open but to recommend the Department to remove Mrs Snodgrass from her present position. Last year she resigned as Field Matron as she did not feel she could carry on as both Teacher & Field Matron.

June 13, 1932
Gerald H. Barry.
Victoria, B.C. District Inspector of Indian Schools, B.C.

Schools:

I visited the Indian Day School on the Bella Coola Indian Reserve. The teacher in charge seems to be rather a hot tempered person and imagines our school Inspector had it in for her. Special Recommendation made in accordance with standing instructions on this subject.

I have the honour to refer the Department of Indian Affairs to my reports on this Bella Coola Indian Day School made after inspections on May 13, 1932, May 12, 1933 and to the special recommendation dated June 13, 1932, as well as to my present report on the school made after my inspection of May 14, 1934.

I beg to state that I do not consider that Mrs. Isabella Snodgrass should be retained as teacher of the Bella Coola Indian Day School after the end of the present School Term ending June 30th, 1934.

My reasons for making such a recommendation have been stated several times. The children are not making the progress which I should like to see in this well equipped school, though it is fair to the present teacher to state that the progress lately has been much greater than in former years. The health of this teacher is a very doubtful quantity. She admits having a leaking valve in her heart. She has had inflamed veins in her leg. I have every reason to consider that her health is such that any energetic teaching is out of the question while this teacher is in charge of this school.

Mrs. Snodgrass appears to have been warned by the authorities of the United Church of Canada that her services would not be required after the end of the present term at the end of June.

She wishes to stay on for another year for financial reasons, and will so request the Department through the Indian Agent at Bella Coola. I do not wish to be hard on this teacher; but I have a duty to the children, and I have every reason to believe that Mrs. Snodgrass will not be left without any money should her services be terminated this June. She has mentioned all about her financial resources to me during my inspection, and have advised her to write to the Department should she so desire. I have however recommended her to take a rest from teaching in an Indian School mainly because her health may not hold out another year, and also because she has a small child of about 8 years of age growing up among the Indians where the exposure to T.B. infection must always be considered.

I would recommend that in place of making a new appointment to fill the vacancy caused by the retirement of Mrs. Snodgrass the position of teacher here be filled by the transfer of Miss Lois Kinley from Division 2 of the Skidegate Indian Day School. Miss Lois Kinley informs me that the United Church is considering recommending a missionary as teacher at Skidegate. Of this I know nothing. I do consider that Miss Lois Kinley would be able to make a very great change in the school at Bella Coola, and that she would be able to take an active interest in the United Church work among the young Indian girls in this village.

Miss Kinley is at present staying with Mr. Indian Agent Todd at Alert Bay; but will be attending the Provincial Summer School in Victoria in July.

I would ask that should the Department agree with me, this recommendation be brought to the attention of the authorities of the United Church of Canada, it being most important to place Miss Lois Kinley a very experienced teacher.

In any case I am unable to recommend the further retention of the services of the present teacher at Bella Coola, Mrs. I. Snodgrass.

Following our conversation the other day and my reference to your communication of August 12th, in regard to the serious decrease in the salary allowed to Miss Ruth E. Young, the teacher of the Bella Coola Indian Day School, I would like to put something on file in regard to the matter.

The teacherage, however, was in poor shape and devoid of furniture, as Mrs. Snodgrass had supplied her own furnishings. Miss Young understood in going there that the question of appointing a married teacher was under consideration. I presume that in setting her salary the Department files were not consulted and that she was regarded as a new appointee, although she had previously served the Department for years.

I am not objecting so much to the rate of $900.00 which has been set for Miss Young for this current year as to the fact that the salary rating having been lowered, it will be difficult, if not impossible, to get it raised again when the teacherage has been repaired and furnished and a suitable married man is available. Miss Young is not using the teacherage but is living in the white village. It might be advisable to get a report from the Indian Agent as to what it would cost to put the teacherage in shape.

SCHOOL:

I visited the Indian Day School on the Bella Coola Reserve. I was most agreeably surprised at the tremendous improvement since my last visit, in every way.

Miss Young, the new teacher, deserves every congratulation. There were 35 children present at the time of my visit out of a roll of 38. This is a big improvement in attendance. The children were well, happy and attentive, instead of scared to death as they were before.

The discipline, however, had not suffered, in fact was really better. Grades 1a and 2 read very well for their ages. Grade 4 was good at reading. Their arithmetic was quite fair and their writing good. The singing of the whole school was good as was their physical training. The scholastic side also was therefore vastly improved. The school room was nice and clean and tidy. Altogether the school is a credit to the teacher and a pleasure to the Indian parents.

Miss Young informs me that her orders for school supplies was delivered very short of request or necessity, particularly in writing paper.

Yours truly,

EXTRACTS from Inspector Barry's Report regarding his inspection of the BELLA COOLA INDIAN DAY SCHOOL on June 2nd, 1937.

Name of teacher: Miss Ruth E. Young.

This teacher is old-fashioned in her teaching of Reading. As mentioned in my last report on this school, she attempts to teach the beginners by a Phonic Method accompanied by pictures which she leaves on the blackboard. She thinks that this is the modern Look and Say Method, which it is not. As mentioned last year, this foolish method of teaching Indian children has led to a very slow "Word for Word" type of Reading now spreading up the school as far as Grade 3.

Though Miss Young is so certain that she is right and that I am wrong, she is not carrying out any modern type of education here that I could discover. Miss Young has purchased the new B.C. Programme of Studies and states that she is following it in part AS THE INDIAN AFFAIRS BRANCH HAS INSTRUCTED HER TO DO ON THE BACK OF HER REGISTER. She intends to ignore my own instruction that this course must only be used as an aid to teachers owing to the fact that in great part it is quite unsuited to our Indian children and their needs.

Much time was given during the previous inspection to outlining limits for the various Grades and Sub Grades and in the teaching of short Demonstration or Type Lessons. This time as well as additional time during the present visit to the school appears to have been wasted. For various reasons touched on later, Miss Ruth Young tells me she has no intention of following my instructions or suggestions, except where she is shown to do so. She states that she has had greater experience of Indians than I have had, having been born and brought up amongst them.

I may say that I was much disturbed by the very strong and hostile statements made by this teacher, as last year she appeared to be very anxious to learn.

The reason for her refusal to follow my suggestions, and I may say that those made last year HAVE NOT BEEN FOLLOWED in any great part, is as follows:

The last Indian Agent, here, Mr. Fouger, while waiting to hand over the Agency to the present Agent, Mr. Gillett, received a copy of my report on the inspection of April 24th, 1936. This report was sent to him from the Assistant Indian Commissioner in Victoria in the usual way. For some undetermined reason, Mr. Fouger permitted Miss Young to have access to and in fact to read my report on the school.

There
There were other factors in the case also and I am of the opinion that Miss Young was very badly advised by others. Mr. Indian Agent Gillett is aware of some of these factors and will no doubt report in confidence to the Indian Affairs Branch if necessary.

The result of all this was that Miss Young became unwilling to follow my advice in her work. She tells me she does not use Two Little Indians as a Pre Primer because she does not like the pictures of the Indians. She says it humiliates the Indian pupils and upsets her to see these pictures. I may say that even if the pictures are not very like the Coast Indians it is the first time in any part of the Province that I have heard that the pictures upset the Indians or teachers.

She tells me that she will not use the Alberta Writing Manuals sent by the Branch to the schools. She is quite hostile to the Indian Affairs Branch and its administration of the Indians as far as I could understand.

There are no teaching posters such as I asked should be made on display. There is little if any of the children's work on display. I regret to say that my efforts to help this teacher have not succeeded.

General:

The school is clean and well ventilated.

The teacher was very impertinent in general. While entitled to consider me useless as an inspector and teacher if she wishes to do this, I do not consider that she is within her rights in speaking to an official of any Government Department in the way she did.

I was so much upset that I asked the Indian Agent to come back into the schoolroom and listen to the definite statements of Miss Young so that there should be no error on my part in recording them.

Miss Young asked if there was no way she could have an independent inspection of the school made, and I replied that as far as I knew there was not, as I was at the moment the only Indian School Inspector in B.C.

The teacher stated that she would make an effort to have someone see my report, probably the Member of Parliament for her own constituency or the Provincial School Inspectors who had seen her work gave her good reports. I may say that so far I have not investigated this matter.

The teacher was most insubordinate.

I have done my very best for her, but I am afraid that fact that she considered my last report on this school adverse, though it was not intended to be such in general, has made it impossible for me to do anything more for Miss Ruth Young.

Dear Major MacKay:

The file of correspondence forwarded with your 15/2/2576 of the 17th instant is returned herewith.

Mr. T.H. Kelly is the only Indian we have on the teaching staff of the Indian Schools in this Province at the present time.

He was moved from Kitselas Indian Day School, Skeena River Agency, to Bella Coola, in September 1937. This transfer was made as he much desired a wider field of action than he could possibly have at Kitselas. His total experience has been a little over one and one half years.

When he called at my office in Vancouver at Christmas time he gave me no warning whatever of a desire to resign.

While I am much displeased, as I know that Dr. Osterhout will also be, at this young man's curt letter of resignation following the hours of work given to aiding him in his professional work, I would recommend that such resignation be accepted by the Department as from Friday afternoon, April 15th and that he be paid up to and including that day only.

I could not recommend the Department to accept a substitute provided by Mr. Kelly, whether such a substitute hold a B.C. Certificate or not. I particularly do not wish to have a local Bella Coola girl placed in charge of the school, where we had so much trouble during my inspection last year.

I would recommend that The Rev. S.S. Osterhout, D.D., 411 Dominion Bank Building, Vancouver, B.C., be supplied with a copy of this file of correspondence, and that he be asked to nominate through you and his own church authorities in Toronto a United Church certificated teacher to take charge of the Bella Coola Indian Day School till June 30th 1938.

I happen to know that Dr. Osterhout has on his list of candidates a well qualified and experienced male teacher, a member of the United Church with Provincial School experience, who would be just the person for Bella Coola in this emergency. I spoke to Dr. Osterhout about this candidate when last in Vancouver.

Following the receipt by telephone or otherwise of the name and qualifications of a qualified teacher nominated by Dr. Osterhout, I would recommend that such teacher be appointed as temporary teacher of the Bella Coola Indian Day School as from April 15th till the end of the school term on June 30th, that is following the Easter vacation. I do not believe that Mr. Kelly is entitled to pay for the period of the Easter Holidays as he does not intend to teach for the remainder of the school year.

Dear Mr. Christie;

Some time ago I wrote to Captain Barry asking for permission to teach the Bella Coola Indian Day School on the half day system, and was told to write you all the details.

The average attendance for October was 38.1, November 35.3, December 46.7 and for January 5 & 6, 51, with an enrollment of 59. Attendance can not be enforced as the school is already overcrowded, and there is no room for more seats. At present two girls are using my desk, four are using an old table and others are sitting at makeshift desks.

There are 29 pupils in Grade 1, and 6 in Grade 2, that need individual attention, which can not be given with all the grades in attendance. Consequently all are losing interest in school work. The half day system, starting at 9 o'clock instead of 9.30 for the older pupils, would enable me to accomplish much more than can be done at present.

Another matter which I would like to bring to your attention is the matter of lighting in the school. The school is finished with dark varnish, so it is very dark most of the time. Due to the high Mountains to the East and South of us the sun can only shine for about an hour during the winter, and we have no artificial light. It is impossible for those sitting at the front to see their work. I would suggest that the walls and ceiling be painted white.

Yours truly,

Dear Sir:

With reference to your letter of December 23, regarding Miss R. Lau's application to operate the Bella Coola Indian Day School on a half-day basis, this matter has been discussed before with Miss Lau, who was asked to make a full report so that I could lay the matter before the Department.

There is no doubt that this school is badly crowded at certain seasons of the year, but on account of the poor attendance during the last quarter—1940 and 1940, I have hesitated in recommending an additional room and teacher. The quarterly average attendance for the past years is as follows:

| Month    | 1939-40 | 1940-41 | 1941-42 |
|----------|---------|---------|---------|
| September| 6.6     | -       | -       |
| December | 16.6    | 46.32   | 36.6    |
| March    | 33.4    | 37.8    |         |
| June     | 16.5    | 13.3    |         |

December and January are usually the months showing largest attendance no doubt due to the fact that all the Indians are home during these months.

There are 51 children on this reserve now under school age and about 8 children on the average will be available for school yearly for the next six years. Those discontinuing school will possibly average about four yearly for the next four years.

The question of a second room and an additional teacher has also been considered and the Indians have been approached with a view to obtaining their consent to sell the old school house back to the Department. It has not been possible to get a vote
on this yet but I have spoken to some of the Band members who purchase this building for Band practice. They will be prepared I think to move the old building and do the necessary work to make the two buildings into one unit of two rooms for $500.00.

However, the Department will no doubt seriously consider the advisability of employing two teachers at this point for longer than six months, that is from October to March since the attendance has always dropped very sharply during the remaining quarter the average for the last two years being 16.3 for 1940 and 13.3 for 1941. There is no question, however, that an increased attendance can be expected with the right kind of teachers and more time by them for individual instruction.

It is of course too late this season to consider the employment of another teacher should same be available, but I would suggest that since the present missionary apparently expects to retire this year, that the United Church should be asked to find a young missionary capable of teaching the older grades from October to March, 1941-42.

In conclusion I would strongly recommend that the Department approve of Miss Lau's suggestion to operate the Bella Coola Indian Day School on a half-day system until the end of March or such time as the average attendance drops to thirty. I am quite sure that more will be accomplished by the children and I have always noted that much more can be got from the junior grades when they are separated from the older pupils.

With the half-day system the teacher will be able to intensify the instruction with a smaller class without the distractions attendant upon trying to teach an overcrowded room of 50 or more pupils in seven different grades.

Miss Lau is in my opinion a conscientious teacher and it will be noted she is prepared to open school half an hour earlier should the Department decide in authorizing the half-day system.

Your obedient servant,

Wm. Christie,
Indian Agent.

Major D. MacKay,
Indian Commissioner for B. C.,
Vancouver, B. C.

REPORT ON BELLA COOLA INDIAN AGENCY FOR THE MONTH NOVEMBER, 1943.

Schools; Day.

All schools in operation were visited and inspected. It is a shame that no teachers are available for Kitamaat and Bella Coola. Attendance at Bella Bella is fairly good, but I am afraid that after the new year, it will take a slump as many of these people are due to go to Namu Cannery for work. The school at Bella Coola is overcrowded. Repairs have been done at Klemtu and the building at least looks clean inside. It will last until better days come and a proper unit can be put up, with teachers quarters attached. It is suggested that at Kitamaat a local Indian with Grade XI standing be appointed interim teacher, to get one room going at least. He seems a fine kind of young man, and he could not be any worse than some white interim or temporary appointments at present in action.

Indian Agent.

REPORT ON BELLA COOLA AGENCY FOR THE MONTH OF DECEMBER, 1943.

Schools:

Day schools at Bella Coola, Klemtu, Bella Bella (2 division) and the empty schoolhouse at Kitamaat were all carefully inspected. Attendance is not satisfactory at all; Klemtu and Bella Coola have most unsuitable persons as teachers; and the closing of the latter school has been recommended. I am afraid that the School at Bella Bella will suffer a serious attendance lapse. War services take men and women in a wholesale manner from the villages winter as well as summer, and if the war goes on much longer, the entire social economy of these Indians will require serious review. In the old days there were at least six months in which the parents would be home; today in some villages, they are home for two weeks at Xmas or for a wedding or funeral; and children by the score are not attending school at all. It is very moot point in my opinion, as to whether home life in Indian villages will ever return to its former status, and I foresee the possibility of "ghost Villages" not long hence. Just where Councils will fit in to the picture of the future is a baffling problem, and future objectives along these lines will need careful study.

F. Earl Anfield,
Indian Agent.

I have received an application from Miss Grace L.M. Farr of 2771 Burdick Avenue, Victoria, for a position as teacher at Bella Coola Indian Day School which has been vacant during the entire term owing to the serious shortage of teachers for such positions.

Miss Farr has had no previous teaching experience but took her Senior Matriculation in 1940 and her second year University in 1942, followed by two years undergraduate nursing training at Victoria Jubilee Hospital. She holds a St. John's Ambulance Certificate and completed a business course including typewriting and shorthand. She is the daughter of Professor Farr who is well known in Victoria.

In view of the lack of professional experience, I referred Miss Farr to Mr. MacKenzie, the Provincial School Inspector in Vancouver, who interviewed her and gave a most enthusiastic report on her fitness for the position considering her lack of training. I also referred her to the Rev. W.P. Bunt of the United Church Home Missions in Vancouver and I understand that he is asking Dr. Dorey to nominate her for the position, expressing himself very well satisfied with her.

As the boat leaves for Bella Coola only once a week, it would be appreciated if you would kindly air mail your approval of this appointment subject to Dr. Dorey's nomination which I am satisfied will be forthcoming and I will then have Miss Farr take the boat sailing on May 2nd as it is felt that she could complete the term and enable both the Department and herself to judge her fitness for continuation of this work for the duration of the war. I understand that it is Miss Farr's intention to take summer school during the vacation. She will have experienced guidance in her work by Mr. Indian Agent Anfield.

Further to our conversation on the possibility of opening a second classroom for this very over-crowded school, a meeting was held with the Bella Coola Silver Band, owners of the old school building of this Reserve, and a resolution was secured granting the use of this building rent free to the Department as a second classroom.

QUARTERLY REPORT ENDING JUNE 30th, 1945, ON BELLA COOLA AGENCY

Education Day Schools in the Agency closed at the end of June, following an academic year of real progress. Schools at Bella Coola, Bella Bella and Kitamaat were inspected by the Provincial Inspector of Schools with very satisfactory reports in all cases. The school at Klemtu was inspected on several occasions by the Agent, who found teaching and other conditions satisfactory. In general there is a noticeably improved interest being shown in all day schools by pupils and parents and the standing of the children is good. Attendance at all schools has improved with the exception of Kitamaat, where the industrial requirements of the adult population resulted in a very unsatisfactory attendance record. At Bella Coola, a second room has been prepared. The teacher during the past year, Miss L. Fleming, has resigned. At Bella Bella, Mrs. D. Martin, senior room teacher resigned and a successor, Mrs. Scott, has been appointed for Sept. 1st. At Kitamaat, Mr. Gordon Robinson, senior room teacher has resigned in order to attend Normal School this winter. Only one teacher will be required at this School this winter.

AGENCY'S REPORT FOR THE QUARTER ENDING DECEMBER 31ST, 1945.

Education: During the past quarter the senior teacher at Bella Bella resigned and has been replaced. It has not been possible to secure a second teacher for Bella Coola. A new school has been established at Upper Dean River at Anahim Lake, but so far no appointment has been made. A second teacher was secured for the Kitamaat school. Attendance on the whole has improved but education in the broader sense of the word is the real weak link in the Indian programme. Right now in B.C. there is no inspector of Indian Schools, qualifications for teaching and calibre of appointments made is generally very low and most schools are seriously overcrowded. These conditions are not conducive of a good response by the pupils and a complete overhauling of the entire educational policy of the Department appears more and more urgent as time goes on. There is a great deal of criticism by the parents of the operation of the Residential Schools and some of this is undoubtedly based on real grievances, caused by unsuitable staffing of the schools in question.

F. Earl Anfield,
Indian Agent.

Dear Mr. Findlay,

Would you kindly forward to the Department of Indian Affairs, Ottawa, this letter - and I would be grateful if you would give my request your favorable recommendation.

Altogether, my experience as a teacher covers thirty-three years, plus, - as follows, - in Ireland as a pupil teacher 3 years, in a teachers' college 2 years as principal of a school 2 years, in Indian schools in British Columbia 25 years - 9 being in Home schools and 17 in Day schools.

In addition I have always taught in Sunday school, given music lessons and helped in various ways. But this year I have taken on no extra work. My age is 63.

When I came here last September it was my intention to stay at least two years, but circumstances may not permit me to do so. The doctor has advised me that I have a heart condition which demands rest and care, which fact coupled with advancing years makes me think that perhaps I should not attempt another year, but retire at the end of this year, instead. I am sure it would be advisable in the interests both of the school and myself.

I am fully aware that there is no pension scheme, in effect, for teachers in Indian schools and knowing this fact I have always been very economical and saving, but it takes a lot of saved money, invested safely (Government Annuity) to give one a liveable return. I feel that after serving the Department as a teacher for over a quarter of a century I would deserve some consideration in the line of a pension. Therefore I would ask the Indian Department for, say, $20.00 per month, which along with what I have would, I think, meet my needs and would help to make the last lap of the journey of life somewhat more comfortable.

Yours faithfully,

CANADA
Indian Day School,
Bella Coola,
B.C.,
Sept. 19, 1925,

The Indian Dept.,
Ottawa

Gentlemen,

I am teacher at the above school.

My salary which I believe through the United Church (Duty) is $50.00 & in addition I was receiving $150.00 bonus direct from the Ind. Dept. I have received no bonus since March 31. Would you kindly let me know if bonus is being discontinued? I understand that it was to be added to salary, but so far it has not been done in my case. I would be grateful for information on this point.

Yours faithfully,

Isabel Shodgraves
Ottawa, September 30, 1925.

Madam,

In reply to your letter of the 19th instant, I beg to say that the payment of bonus to teachers on Indian day schools has been discontinued from March 31st, last.

The Department has decided to increase the salaries of teachers in Indian day schools by $150.00 from April 1st, last. Your salary is now at the rate of $90.00 for each teaching month and a cheque for $270.00, being the amount for the June quarter, was sent to the treasurer of the Methodist Missionary Society.

I note from your letter that you have already received from him $225.00 and I understand that he has recently forwarded to you a cheque for the balance, namely, $45.00.

Your obedient servant,

Russell T. Ferrier,
Supt. of Indian Education.

Mrs. Isabel Snodgrass,
Teacher,
Indian Day School,
Bella Coola,
B. C.

Ottawa, April 23, 1931.

Sir:

I have your letter of the 5th instant, informing the Department that Mrs. Isabel Snodgrass, teacher and field matron at Bella Coola, desires to give up her duties as field matron, provided she suffers no loss in salary. The reasons stated for Mrs. Snodgrass' desire to relinquish the position of field matron have been noted.

The Department will approve of her discontinuing field matron's duties, and will allow her an increase in her salary as teacher of the Bella Coola Indian Day School from May 1st, next. Our funds are extremely limited for the present fiscal year, and the amount of the increase we could allow her for teaching services would be at the rate of $10 per teaching month. This will make her total salary as teacher from the above date at the rate of $1050 per year. I shall be pleased if you will take up this matter with Mrs. Snodgrass and ascertain if she will discontinue field matron's duties, in view of the increase allowed her for teaching duties, and advise the Department accordingly.

Your obedient servant,

A. F. MacKenzie,
Secretary.

I. Fougner, Esq.,
Indian Agent,
Bella Coola, B.C.
Ottawa, May 19, 1931.

Sir:

I have your letter of the 5th instant, informing the Department that Mrs. Isabel Snodgrass will discontinue duties as field matron at Bella Coola as from the 1st instant, and will accept an increase in her salary for the performing of the teaching services only. The total salary allowed her as teacher will be as stated in official letter of the 23rd ultimo, viz., $105 per teaching month, ten months in the year. You will, therefore, discontinue her name on the pay list from the above date. Vouchers in payment of her salary as teacher will be prepared in the Department.

Your obedient servant,

A. F. MacKenzie,
Secretary.

I. Fouger, Esq.,
Indian Agent,
Bella Coola, B.C.

CANADA
Ottawa, August 3, 1936.

Sir:

I have to inform you that the authorities of the United Church of Canada have nominated the services of Miss Ruth E. Young as teacher of the Bella Coola Indian Day School, to succeed Mrs. Isabel Snodgrass, who retired.

The Department is approving the appointment of Miss Young, to begin duties when the school re-opens after the present holidays, on September first, next. The salary allowed her will be at the rate of $90.00 per teaching month. Please give her every possible assistance as she takes up her duties at this school.

Mr. C. C. Perry, Asst. Indian Commissioner, is being informed of the approval granted for the appointment of Miss Young.

Your obedient servant,

A. F. MacKenzie,
Secretary.

I. Fouger, Esq.,
Indian Agent,
Bella Coola, B. C.

Memorandum:

REPRESENTATIVE OF THE TREASURY

Re: Bella Coola Indian Day School, No. 803.

Philip Phelan,
Chief, Training Division.
Ottawa,
December 7, 1943.

Memorandum:

REPRESENTATIVE OF THE TREASURY

Re: Bella Coola Indian Day School, No. 803.

The Department appointed Rev. Thomas Moore as teacher of this school at a salary of $50.00 a month, effective October 1, 1943. I enclose T.D. 1 form, head of household declaration form and copy of letter of appointment. Staff questionnaire will reach you shortly.

Philip Phelan,
Chief, Training Division.
Ottawa,
December 15, 1943.

Memorandum:

REPRESENTATIVE OF THE TREASURY

Re: Bella Coola Indian Day School No. 803

Please note that Reverend Thomas Moore is giving up duties as teacher of this school, effective January 1, 1944, and no payment of salary should be made to him after this month.

Miss N.L. Paul has been appointed teacher for the period January 1 to June 30, 1944, at a salary of $100.00 a teaching month. I enclose copy of letter of appointment and the usual forms will be forwarded to you as soon as received.

Philip Phelan,
Chief, Training Division.
Ottawa,
January 3, 1944.

Memorandum:

REPRESENTATIVE OF THE TREASURY

Re: Bella Coola Indian Day School, No. 805.

In the second paragraph of my memorandum of December 15, I advised you that Miss N.L. Paul had been appointed teacher of the above-mentioned school, effective January 1. I am now advised that Miss Paul will not accept the position and consequently her name should not be placed on the pay-list.

Philip Melan,
Chief, Training Division.
Ottawa,
May 27, 1944.

Memorandum:

REPRESENTATIVE OF THE TREASURY

Re: Bella Coola Indian Day School
No. 803

The Department has appointed Miss Grace L.M. Parr as teacher of this school. She began duties on May 5, 1944, at a salary of $100 a teaching month, plus bonus. I enclose copy of letter of appointment and T.D. 1 form. Staff questionnaire will reach you shortly.

for Deputy Minister.
Ottawa,
December 14, 1944.

Memorandum:

REPRESENTATIVE OF THE TREASURY

Re: Bella Coola Indian Day School, No. 803.

We have just been informed that Miss Grace L.M. Farr did not return to duties at the above-mentioned school on September 1. I understand she has been paid to June 30 and no further payment should be made to her.

To succeed her the Department has appointed Miss Laura Fleming at a salary of $105 a teaching month, effective September 29, 1944. We have just been notified of her taking over duties at the school on the date mentioned and it would be appreciated if you would arrange to issue immediately a cheque for her services for the period September 29 to November 30 at the rate mentioned above. As soon as we receive the necessary forms they will be forwarded to you. I enclose copy of letter of appointment.

Miss Fleming's cheque should be sent by air mail.

for Deputy Minister.
Ottawa, June 13, 1945.

Memorandum:

REPRESENTATIVE OF THE TREASURY.

Re: Bella Coola Indian Day School,
No. 803.

The Department has received and accepted the resignation of the teacher, Miss L. M. Fleming, effective July 1, 1945, and no further payment of salary should be made to her after that date.

For Deputy Minister.
Ottawa, October 22, 1945.

Memorandum:

REPRESENTATIVE OF THE TREASURY

Re: Bella Coola Indian Day School,
No. 803,

In my memorandum of June 13, 1945, you were advised of the resignation of Miss L. M. Fleming as teacher of the above-noted school, effective July 1, 1945.

To succeed her, the Department has approved the appointment of Miss Anne Wright as teacher of this school. Salary will be allowed her at the rate of $105.00 a teaching month, plus bonus, effective October 11, 1945.

I enclose copy of letter of appointment, T.D.I form and cost-of-living bonus form. Staff questionnaire will be submitted to you shortly.

For Deputy Minister.

Encl.

Re: Klemtu Indian Day School, No. 805,
Re: Bella Coola Indian Day School, No. 803,

Mrs. Isabel Snodgrass, teacher of the Klemtu school, will give up duties at that school, effective July 1, 1946.

It has been decided to transfer her to the senior room at the Bella Coola school, effective September 1, 1946, at a salary of $105.00 a teaching month, plus bonus.

I will advise you later regarding the name of the teacher who will be in charge of the Klemtu school for the academic year 1946-47.

Sir:

I beg to advise that there are more pupils attending the day school at Bella Coola than before, and the seating accommodation is inadequate. There are two empty single desks without seats; and two chairs with shortened legs would meet the need, and are requested.

A few pupils have to sit quite close to the stove. A screen (wooden frame with asbestos sides) would give protection from the heat, and authority to get screens made is requested.

I cannot say exactly what the cost will be of chairs and screen, but should be below $15.00.

Obediently yours,

Indian Agent.

Sir:

Sir:

Mr. Inspector Barry, in a report on his recent inspection of the Bella Coola Indian Day School, recommends that, in order to accommodate the increasing number of children at this school, the partition between the actual schoolroom and hall be removed. He states that this would not cost much and would provide space for the number of children expected in September. He states that, if this is done, and a number of extra desks supplied, it would not be necessary to conduct the school on the half-day system, as there would be ample accommodation for all the children.

I have to request that you will furnish an estimate of the cost of having the partition removed and the enlarged classroom placed in good condition. Your early reply is requested, in order that, if the work is authorized, it can be carried out during the coming summer holidays.

The Inspector has given the number and sizes of the extra desks that would be required if the classroom is enlarged, and we would be prepared to supply same.

The Inspector recommends that the new fence, which was placed along the front of the school lot only, be continued around the remaining three sides. You should furnish an estimate of the cost of the material and labour required in fencing the balance of the school lot.

A small looking glass is required at this school, and you may arrange for the purchase of same, forwarding a certified account, in triplicate, covering the cost.

Your obedient servant,

A. F. MacKenzie,
Secretary.

EXTRACT FROM INSPECTOR BARRY'S REPORT REGARDING HIS INSPECTION OF THE BELLA COOLA INDIAN DAY SCHOOL ON APRIL 26, 1935.

The buildings, which belong to the Department of Indian affairs, consist of a schoolroom with a small walled off hall, a teacher's cottage of four rooms which is not furnished by the Department, a small woodshed, and two toilets. Everything was perfectly neat and clean when I inspected. The new fence previously recommended to be placed around the school grounds of about one acre, has now been placed along the front only. I would recommend that the new fence be continued around the remaining three sides.

To accommodate the increasing number of children at this school, I would recommend that the partition between the actual schoolroom & the hall be removed. This would not cost much and would provide space for the number of children expected in September. If the Department agrees to this and provides the extra desks recommended below, I do not think that it will be necessary to conduct this school on the HALF DAY SYSTEM which the Indians dislike so much, but which gives fairly good results nevertheless. I could not recommend the building of a second schoolroom here at the present time.

A small looking glass is also needed.

The following school desks are required: (Numbers refer to Crown Desks, Vancouver, B.C.)

- 2 Rear Sections Number 4
- 6 Desk Sections Number 4
- 4 Front Sections Number 3 and 2 Desk Sections Number 3.

The above is the minimum necessary to care for the increased attendance, and if supplied will make it possible to have all the children in school at once if the necessary structural changes are made to the classroom as recommended above.

Sir,

In account of the recent floods taking out the bridges between the white townsite and the Indian village of Bella Coola, I have found it necessary to make temporary arrangements for Miss Young, the teacher, to be taken by Indian canoe back and forth across the river daily. I do not think it worth while for the Department to spend any money on the residence, as the village people have determined to leave the present site, because of its dangerous position in regard to floods. Dear Sir,

Has the Department a plan of a one-room school suitable to accommodate approximately forty children? The Department is aware that when the Bella Coola Indians move to their new townsite, a school will have to be erected. I had thought that it would be economical to take down the old school building and teacherage, and use the suitable lumber, but on account of the cost of transportation across the river, breakage, extra handling etc., I think it would be far more practical to provide an entirely new building. The two old buildings could possibly be sold to Indians, so that they could be taken down at their own convenience, for what good lumber there is in them.

On account of the delay in getting the new townsite sub-divided, it was not possible for the Indians to make any preparations last spring towards moving, as they had anticipated. The survey is now being carried out, but the Indians are away fishing and will not be returning until October. They will then have to clear the lots and streets, and lay in the water system etc. In the circumstances, therefore, it is not likely that they will be able to move over until well on towards Christmas.

The Bella Coola school will open in September, as usual, in their old village, but there is no doubt in my mind that the Indians will be in their new village before the end of the present fiscal year. Will funds be available, therefore, for the erection of a new school. Once the people have moved over, it would be impossible to transport the children back and forth across the river in order to continue to use the present school.

If the Department will send me a plan, I could then ascertain the approximate cost of materials etc.

Your obedient servant,

J. Gillett,
Indian Agent.

Dear Sir,

Your file 163-7-5, Dec. 23rd, 1937

Re: Day School on new Bella Coola townsite

At present there are six houses occupied on the new townsite, and ten more under construction. The whole matter of moving the people was delayed on account of not receiving word from the Department giving approval of the move, early enough to clear the townsite of timber etc., last spring before the Indians were moved. On Feb. 25th, 1937, when the surveyor had completed the laying out of the townsite, the streets and a number of the lots were cleared last fall. The majority of the Indians have postponed moving until the spring, on account of bad weather conditions. There are only five children on the new townsite. School is being kept open in the school in the old village.

When I wrote on Feb. 25th, 1937, I thought word would be received from the Department sanctioning the move, soon enough to get the people moved before school opened in September. I had hoped therefore to get the school moved during the summer holidays. I recommended at that time that the old school be taken down. However, since school had to be opened in the old village and after going further into the matter, I thought it better to build a new school, taking into consideration the breakage of lumber in moving and the cost of transportation. Also a larger school is required. In my letter of August 13th, 1937, No. 8429, I advised the selling of the old school and teacher's residence.

The Department wrote me on August 26th and sent plans of a new school. I returned those plans with my recommendations on Sept. 13th.

I would still suggest that a new school be built. The cost of material would be approximately $1500, if I am allowed to get competitive prices, as I already have some quotations. Cost of labour would be approximately $2000.

It is not possible that a new school could be built before March 31st next. I would recommend however, if money is available, that the lot be cleared and the basement excavated before the end of the present fiscal year. The approximate cost would be $500 including lumber for cement forms, which can later be used in the construction of the school building. If this meets with the Department's approval, I would suggest that an advance accountable cheque for $300 for labour, be sent immediately Local labour can be secured.

Your obedient servant,

J. Gillett,
Indian Agent.

Memorandum:

MR. BAILEY

With reference to my memorandum of February 17 and your reply of February 21 regarding the material in the school and teacher's residence on the present townsite of the Bella Coola Indians the following information has been received from our Agent:

1. Day School on Bella Coola Reserve

This was erected in 1910 at an approximate cost of $1000.00. It is 36'6" by 20'4" by 11'. The approximate amount of lumber in the building is 6,500 feet. Some of the sills are rotten. I have been offered $125 for the building as it stands, by one of the Indians. I consider this a good offer. It would not pay the Department to take down the school and use the lumber in the new school, because of the cost of labour, transportation and breakage. Better value would be obtained by purchasing $125.00 worth of new lumber. I would recommend that the offer of $125.00 be accepted.

2. School Teacher's Residence Bella Coola Reserve

This building was erected in 1924 at an approximate cost of $900.00. It is 24' by 24' by 9', and contains approximately 6000 feet of lumber, but of a poorer grade than that used in the school. I have been offered $100.00 for it. The same conditions apply to the salvage of lumber as in the case of the school. In both cases, however, an Indian using his own time in dismantling etc., could get good value for the money paid for the buildings. I recommend that the offer of $100.00 be accepted.
You will note from the above that the Agent recommends that these buildings be demolished after June 30, 1938.

He has not given the name of the Indians who have offered to purchase the material in both buildings but if this information is necessary it can be obtained.

Director.

Dr. H.W. McGill,

As you are aware, we are unable to dispose of Government property except through the Salvage Officer and then usually by tender. It would, therefore, seem desirable to refer any tenders to that Officer.

Dear Sir,

As requested by telegram of February 17th I am forwarding herewith a list of material required for the proposed Indian Day school for the new Bella Coola Townsite. Attached also is the Rexwell Lumber Company's price on the lumber.

I may say that I have made no provision for toilets. I believe it will be possible to have inside toilets as the Indians intend putting a sewage system in the village. I will take this matter up later.

The enclosed estimates are based on the blue-print sent by the Department, No. 710, but without the teacher's quarters. The cement for the basement is figured on an 8-inch wall, instead of 10-inch. An 8-inch wall is quite sufficient in this locality.

I have estimated on a building 24 feet wide, instead of 25 feet as shown in plan, as 25 is an odd size and would require each piece of lumber to be cut.

The nearest sawmill to Bella Coola is the Telegraph Cove Mill, and I have sent them a list of the material and asked them to furnish their quotations to the Department direct. The freight rates from Telegraph Cove would be less than from Vancouver.

Cement can be landed at Bella Coola dock by Sam King, local Indian merchant, for $1.15 per sack. This is the best local price.

Your obedient servant,

Re: Bill of Materials required for new Day School, Bella Coola, B.C.

Recommendations.

1. Cement. Based on the use of 8" foundation walls, 1'6" x 9" footings, and a 4" floor slab, it is estimated that using a 1:6 mix, 300 sacks cement will be required.

2. Brick. Based on a 4" brick chimney with 8½" x 13" flue, erected on concrete base below 1st floor line, 800 brick will be satisfactory. If, however, chimney is erected in brick from basement floor slab, 1000 brick will be required.

3. Flue lining. It is noted that flue lining is not provided in the bill of material, and if a 4" brick chimney is used, it will be necessary to provide a clay tile flue lining. 12 pcs. 8½" x 13" x 2'0" flue lining will be required.

4. Building Paper. Based on lining roof under shingles, both sides exterior walls, ceiling sheathing and subflooring. 6,000 sq.ft. of building paper would be required.

5. Furnace. No provision is made for pipe connection from furnace pipe to chimney. This would require only 8" black iron flue thimble for 8" wall (maximum).

No provision is made for chimney cleanout. This would require:
1 only 8" x 10" C.I. Cleanout Door & Frame for 8" wall.

Memorandum:

DEPUTY MINISTER

Provision has been made in our estimates for the fiscal year 1938-39 for the erection of a new day school on the Bella Coola Indian Reserve, Bella Coola Agency, Electoral District of Skeena, Province of British Columbia.

If the materials for this building were purchased before the end of March and paid for out of the current year's appropriation it would greatly assist us in carrying out our proposed building program during the fiscal year 1938-39. Funds are available for the purchase of the material for this school from our appropriation for the fiscal year 1937-38. I enclose two quotations which the Indian Agent obtained from firms near the proposed school. These quotations were submitted to the Surveys & Engineering Branch and they state that if either tender is accepted there would be practically all the lumber etc. that will be required.

I also enclose list showing hardware, paint and cement that would be necessary. If a list of these articles were forwarded to Indian Commissioner Mackay of Vancouver he could arrange for purchase before the end of March. Vancouver would be the best point to purchase the hardware etc. as there is direct boat connection from Vancouver to Bella Coola.

I enclose two requisitions, one for the lumber and the other for the hardware.
I would appreciate if the Honourable the Minister would authorize the Purchasing Agent to proceed at once with the purchase of the materials required for the erection of this building. As stated above, funds for the purpose are available in our appropriation for the fiscal year ending March 31, 1938.

Director.

Dear Sir:

With reference to your letter of February 22 I desire to advise you that an order is being placed with Telegraph Cove Mills Limited for the lumber and mill work required for the Bella Coola Indian Day School at the amount mentioned in their quotation to you; namely, $720.00. The Department is also arranging to purchase the hardware, paint, cement and furnace that will be required for this school.

It is hoped to have these supplies delivered in the near future in order that the accounts may be dated previous to March 31 and this will permit our paying them from the current year's appropriation.

Please let me know at once if you consider that this building should be erected by day labour or by contract. If you recommend day labour—presumably employing Indians—will it be necessary to secure a white foreman or any other skilled labour. If so you should let me know exactly what tradesmen will be necessary.

Memorandum:

DEPUTY MINISTER

With reference to Mr. Jackson's memorandum of March 18 and my reply of March 22 in connection with the Bella Coola Indian Day School the following telegram has just been received from Indian Agent Gillett:

RE DEPARTMENTAL LETTER MARCH TWENTY SECOND RECOMMEND SCHOOL ERECTED BY INDIAN DAY LABOR ONE WHITE LOCAL FOREMAN STOP OTHER SKILLED LABOR UNNECESSARY STOP ALL NECESSARY MATERIAL NOW ON THE GROUND STOP RECOMMEND IMMEDIATE START ON CONSTRUCTION AND THAT ADVANCE CHEQUE FOR EIGHT HUNDRED DOLLARS BE SENT

In view of the fact that with the exception of a white foreman skilled Indian labour is available and that the necessary material is now on the ground I heartily concur with the recommendation of Mr. Gillett to erect this building by day labour.

In Vote 165, for the fiscal year 1938-39, the amount of $56,000.00 was provided for new day schools. This included an item of $4,000.00 for the Bella Coola day school. Application has recently been made to the Treasury Board for the transfer of the amount of $56,000.00 to the Surveys and Engineering Branch. If this transfer is approved the advance requested by Indian Agent Gillett would have to be forwarded by the Surveys and Engineering Branch.

Director.

Dear Sir,

I enclose herewith the Returns of Labour in connection with clearing the lot for the new school on Bella Coola Reserve, and also a statement showing the expenditure of the cheque for $300.00. The cost of clearing lot and excavating the basement has cost up to date, $500. This was authorized by letter No. 162-7-5 of January 22nd, 1938.

This was a harder proposition than was anticipated. After we had the timber off we found just below the surface large boulders, covering the whole lot, 150 ft by 300 ft. Fortunately we were able to hire a bulldozer, otherwise the work could never have been satisfactorily by hand labour, and the cost would have been tremendous. There are still a number of boulders to be removed, and the stumps to be burned after they have dried out. The lot is now fairly level, but still very stoney and gravel should be hauled to make it suitable for a playground. Another hundred dollars should complete the work. The basement is ready for the cement forms.

I am enclosing some pictures taken as the work progressed. I will secure one of the lot as it now is, and send later.

Your obedient servant,

Dear Sir:

The Department received your letters of the 31st ultimo and 4th instant enclosing pictures in connection with the clearing of the site at the new Bella Coola Indian Day School. I was very glad to receive these pictures.

Dear Sir:

The Bella Bella and Klemtu Bands were visited during the month, although most of my time was spent on the Bella Coola Reserve.

Three schools were visited during March. There was a good attendance at Bella Bella and at Klemtu. At Bella Coola the attendance averaged nine pupils, due to the fact that the majority of the people have moved to their new townsite. After giving due consideration to the transportation of the pupils across the river, I decided that the risks were too great. It therefore means that until the new school is built the majority of the Bella Coola children are without schooling. If I have word early in April to begin construction, there is no reason why the school could not be ready by the middle of May. By that time it is likely that all the children will be living on their side of the river. I may say that most of the building material for the new school is already on the ground and the basement excavation ready for the cement forms.

J. Gillett,
Indian Agent.

Dear Sir,

I have today moved all the school furnishings, desks etc., from the old school on Bella Coola Reserve to the Church on the new townsite, where school will be held until the end of this term. I found this action necessary, as there are now no school children left in the old village, and it does not appear that the new school will be built in time to be of use this spring.

I secured permission from the Clergyman in charge, to use the Church on the understanding that I would recommend to the Department XXX a rental of $10.00 per month for the next two months. The Church was recently moved over intact, and the rental will help towards defraying the cost of this.

Memorandum:

Dr. McGill,

Re - Water supply for new Bella Bella School, Bella Coola Indian Reserve, B.C.

The Indian Agent has suggested a plan for providing a water service to the new school from the village water system. It appears that as the school is on fairly high ground, the pressure will not ensure an adequate supply unless certain tank storage is available. The Indian Agent has suggested that a small tank be installed and connected to the standard equipment planned for the school. The total cost of the tank installation, plus some 500 feet of piping to connect the school system with the village system, is estimated at approximately $300.

It would not be proposed to undertake this installation or make any expenditure until one of our Engineers has checked the matter up on the ground, but in the meantime, you might kindly advise me if you would be willing to make the above expenditure.

Director.

Extract from Inspector Coleman's report on his inspection of the Bella Coola Indian Agency in October, 1941.

SCHOOL This was visited while in session and an endeavour made to give the teacher some assistance, but no inspection was made of the academic work of the children. The school is too small to accommodate all the children of school age in the village and the teacher finds difficulty in dealing with a large class, with the result that interest in the school is falling off. Matters could be improved considerably by enlarging the school to two rooms. There is an excellent school building in the old village but unfortunately the Department sold this to the Band for $100 for use as a Band Practice Hall; at present it is standing idle. It may be found possible to purchase it back at a slightly higher price and move it over next to the present school and connect the two buildings together, as the old school appears to be quite sound. If this could be done for about $500 and another teacher secured the attendance would probably double and the quality of the teaching be improved by division of the junior grades from the senior. The matter is being taken up by the Agent and if the proposal appears possibly by the Band agreeing to the sale of the old building, he will make application to the Department, furnishing a survey of all the children of the village up to the age of fifteen years.

The appearance of the school grounds could be considerably improved by the planting of a few trees along the edge of the lot and some shrubs around the base of the building. At present it is very bare in appearance.

The present teacher, Miss Lau, appears to be capable but not at all cheerful by nature.

Dear Sir:

I beg to forward herewith Inspector Coleman's report on his inspection of the Bella Coola Indian Agency. Although the inspection of the Agency was completed in October last, certain delays occurred in the preparation of the report which accounts for the delay in its submission to the Department.

The following observations are made on various matters dealt with in the report:

Page 13. School.

I am enclosing herewith Return of labour, for work performed at the Bella Coola Indian Day School.

There were several windows broken in the basement, and hall way, both front door locks were loose, and the doors loose on the hinges, so I had new glass put in, the locks repaired, and doors properly hung again.

The teacher also complained of lack of seating space in the class room; I investigated this and found several children sitting on boxes and broken chairs, there is seating for about 38 children, and this included two double desks, which is not a satisfactory arrangement, but under the circumstances these will have to be used for the time being.

I had two old double desks which I found in the basement, put together again, and these are also used, as there has been over 45 pupils attending some days.

I have paid the cost of this labour out of personal funds, and receipt for same is attached to Return of Labour.

A large cupboard is badly needed in the basement, for keeping paper towels, toilet paper, soap, and other materials in.

The children will waste about half the items mentioned, if they can get their hands on them, so I would suggest a locked cupboard.

I have received an application from Mr. Indian Agent Anfield for authority to expend the sum of $75.00 for the improvement of the school grounds at Bella Coola. It is proposed to commence fencing the grounds and make other improvements and continue the work in another fiscal year when funds may be available to complete the scheme in mind. Mr. Anfield does not state what the total cost of the project will be.

In this connection, I would advise that unless the Department particularly wishes to commence the work this year, I would suggest that the matter of these improvements be left until the new addition to the school to provide for a teacher's quarters and another classroom has been approved. Provision was made for this construction in the program of worthwhile works to be undertaken immediately following the close of the war and I should think that the improvements Mr. Anfield has in mind could best be made at that time.

There is no regular teacher at Bella Coola at present. It will be recalled that the Department approved the temporary employment of the local United Church missionary as teacher for this school until such time as the services of a properly qualified teacher could be secured.
