October 27th, 1945.

Major D. M. MacKey, Indian Commissioner for B.C., Vancouver, B.C.

Re: Temporary classroom - Bella Coola Day School

Authority is requested to spend $48.00 to complete the work on this classroom. Cupboards will have to be built; floors lined up and oiled and the new and old desks uncrated, set up and put on runners on the floor.

We have sufficient lumber on hand in the Agency to put in a full set of cupboards and an accountable cheque for the labour is requested.

The one room in operation is filled to capacity and has been put on a half day basis. A second teacher is needed. The room can be put in condition to open with three days work for a carpenter and two helpers.

F. Earl Anfield,
Indian Agent.

When arrangements were made for the opening of a second classroom at Bella Coola, the matter of toilet facilities was seemingly entirely overlooked.

The building is some considerable distance from the school (the new one) and some sanitary arrangements will have to be made for the convenience of the pupils. I would suggest that separate outside toilets be erected a short distance behind the school.

Since no provisions had been made to protect the wood supply which is piled up near the school in inclement weather, I would also suggest that a lean-to wood shed be erected at the rear of the building.

Shelves have been erected inside the school for storing supplies and doors should be provided to turn these into a cupboard.

August 6, 1947.

Major D. M. MacKay, Indian Commissioner for B. C., Vancouver, B. C.

Re: Bella Coola Indian Day School - Senior Room

In this mail is going forward my proposal for certain additions to the above building in cooperation with the Indian owners who have donated the use of the building to the school for the past year and are willing to continue the arrangement meantime.

It is many years since the interior of this building has been decorated and it presents a most drab and dirty appearance. The floor is particularly in need of attention. I have been trying for some time to secure a tender for the work of painting the floor, wainscoting, walls, and ceilings, also removing desks from floor and screwing them onto strips in accordance with more recent accepted practice. Floors, wainscoting will require two coats of paint, walls and ceiling will require washing to remove old calcimine and two coats of paint to finish. There is no one here either white or Indian, capable and willing to do the work just now. However had I the materials on hand I might find someone with the time to spare within the next month or so. I estimate that this work should be finished in about seven men days and if I had authority to spend $60.00 should be able to pay the labor and buy the stripping for the desks and any other small items of material that may be required, in addition to the following list of paint which I would appreciate your assistance in purchasing providing the work is approved:

2 gal. Medium Gray Floor enamel
2½ " Cream Inside paint
1½ " Pearl house paint (for ceiling).

Attached are duplicate quotations that Mr. Levelton has secured from three firms. Marshall-Wells price is slightly the more favorable. Paint should be shipped via Union S.S. marked "For Day School" and addressed c/o Indian Agent, Bella Coola, B. C.

May I have your early authority to proceed with this work.

W. P. Bruden,
Indian Agent.

Ottawa, September 5, 1947.

Major D.M. MacKay, Indian Commissioner, P.O. Box 70,
Vancouver, B.C.,

With reference to your letter of the
3rd instant, the Department approves an expenditure
of $140.00 for improvements required to the building
used as a Senior classroom at the Bella Coola Indian
Day School.

Philip Phelan,
Chief, Training Division.

PP/HM.
Indian Affairs Branch, Dept. of Mines & Resources, Ottawa.

I am enclosing Mr. Indian Agent Pruden's letter of August 6, in connection with improvements required to the building used as a senior classroom, Bella Coola Indian Day School.

Inasmuch as the building has been used rent free for some time and will continue to be used until new construction is provided, it is considered reasonable that the Department make some expenditure for improvements. The requirements listed by Mr. Pruden will cost approximately $140.00 and it will be appreciated if you would advise if this amount can be made available.

D. M. MacKay,
Indian Commissioner for B.C.
Bella Coola, B.C.,
August 6th, 1947.

Major D. M. MacKay, Indian Commissioner for B.C., Vancouver.

Re: Bella Coola Indian Day School
Senior Room (Gordon Band Hall)

During the past year a Bella Coola Indian musical organization known as the Gordon Band have kindly donated their band practice hall to the use of the senior room of the Day School, rent free. During the coming year they are willing to continue the arrangement and it would appear in view of the amount of school construction urgently required in this Agency that I may have to ask them to forego the use of their practice hall in the interests of the school children for several years to come.

The building is not suitable for a school room as it stands. It is the same building that was used as a school in the old village across the river. On being reconstructed on this side there was not sufficient lumber to construct an entry or vestibule and the present doorway opens directly from the classroom to the open air. Last winter rain beating against the door caused pools of water on the floor.

The wood was piled in the open and as a result was covered with wet snow and considerable difficulty was experienced in keeping the fires going.

Since the building is occupied rent free, the owners can hardly be asked to make good these deficiencies. However several Indians have expressed their willingness to donate labor to remedying the situation. I propose that in recognition of the obligation of the Department to house the school that materials be donated for the construction of an entry of sufficient size to accommodate the children's wraps and a small quantity of fuel for day to day use and where washing facilities may be placed. Further, that materials also be donated for a wood shed to accommodate the annual fuel supply. All of the above on the understanding that the Bella Coola Indians supply the labor in recognition of the permanent improvement to the building.

(over)
Indian Affairs Branch, Dept. of Mines & Resources,
Ottawa.

Under date of September 5th the Department approved an expenditure of $140 for improvements required to the building used as a senior classroom at the Bella Coola Indian Day School. This amount was intended to cover the cost of materials only, it being understood at that time that the owner of the building, which the Department has the use of rent free, would provide the necessary labour. Mr. Indian Agent Pruden has advised, however, that in spite of many promises that the work would be done immediately the repairs and improvements have not yet been attended to.

The cost of labour is estimated at $120.00 and I would recommend that the Department approve an expenditure of this amount as it would appear that we will have to use the building in question for classroom purposes for at least another year. I would recommend that an accountable advance of $120 be forwarded to Mr. Pruden after April 1st and that in the meantime he be authorized to have the work proceeded with.

W.T. Arneil,

Re: Bella Coola Day School (Senior Room)

Thank you for your 2-11-3 of March 17th giving authority to proceed with the construction of wood-shed and entry to the above named school building.

Work is now in hand and should be completed within a week. With reference to the last paragraph of your letter, since this work is being completed by contract and not by day labor I believe I am correct in assuming that paylists and hour rates will not be applicable, since these are entirely the concern of the contractor.

The same native contractor has undertaken to paint the interior and as the school is now on holiday and this is the first offer of painting I have had since the painting materials arrived last September, I have ordered the work to proceed. This work will also be on a contract basis and the price will be higher than I estimated originally. The contractor has agreed to do the work for $85.00 and considering the very exacting work needed to remove the old calcimine I agree that this is not excessive.

There remains on hand from accountable advance of August 21st ($22 cheque 61940) the sum of $41.70. This is being paid on account to the contractor. Accounting voucher with receipts is going forward to Ottawa. Additional authority for $43.30 to complete payment for the paint work is therefore required. Re: Bella Coola Day School

The building occupied by the above school is the property of the "Gorion Band" a musical organization made up of members of the Bella Coola Band of Indians. This organization have given the building without charge to the Department for the past three school terms.

In the meantime, the musical group having no place to practice, neglected what had been a very fine silver band. During the past year I have been told by individuals of the Bella Coola Band that they considered the neglect of music an important factor in the increase of drunkenness in the village. Acting on this theory last autumn, some of the head men of the village reorganized the band and began practicing in the homes. By Christmas they were doing very well. It was then decided to start a Junior Band to train the young men. The group has now grown so large that it is impossible to accommodate them in a dwelling. It is desired to hold classes often with so many beginners.

In view of this, the Council reluctantly approached me to enquire about the senior school building. They had originally been told that the loan was for only one year. Now I have had to tell them that it would appear that a school room could not be constructed here for several years and that if their band hall is returned, then the senior room must be closed. This of course they do not wish. A very poor second choice for the band classes is to try to squeeze in practice sessions between other events in the large village hall. This building is normally busy every week night with basketball, ring hockey, moving pictures, banquets, concerts and the occasional dance. In order to improve the finances of this building an increased scale of rentals has been imposed. Since most of the activity in this hall is of a community nature, it is not possible to modify the rates schedule without upsetting the hall's finances. The band must therefore pay rental for use of this hall and they have not enough funds to do so.

Indian Affairs. (RG 10, Volume 6385, File 803-5, part 4)
It seems to me that the time has come to allow the "Gordon Band" some rental for the use of their building. This rental could be applied toward the rental they must pay for the larger hall. The minimum they will require will be about $2.50 per practice, ten times per month, covering the Junior and Senior groups.

I recommend that a rental of $15.00 per month be authorized to be paid to the Gordon Band for the use of their building as Senior Day School room, this rental to be retroactive to September 1943.

T. P. Fadden,
Superintendent,
Indian Agency.
Indian Affairs Branch, Dept. of Mines and Resources,
Ottawa

W. S. Arneil, Indian Commissioner for B.C., Vancouver, B.C.

Re PLUMBING, BELLA COOLA DAY SCHOOL

Referring to your letter of November 21, file 2-11-3, please be advised that the labour return covers repairs to the one remaining toilet tank and bowl also to dismantling and removal of broken bowl and pipes.

A voucher covering return of labour in favour of Robert Moody is herewith attached.

We shall endeavour to get an estimate on the cost of installing new toilet bowl and pipes. It is quite evident that some very necessary repairs will have to be made in connection with the flooring in the toilets as I noticed on my last visit that the floor boards appeared to be rotten.

Apparently the board floor is laid over a part of the basement floor which was not cemented at time of construction and evidently dry rot has set in owing to lack of ventilation and also to a leak in one of the pipes. It is very hard to estimate closely on the actual cost of these repairs because it may be necessary to tear out the two board walls and partition to enable the workman to get the old floor out and to renew same. If the cement floor does not extend through under the board floor, I think it would be good economy to cement in the whole floor and just sit the toilet bowls on the cement and eliminate the board floor entirely. I would estimate the total cost at approximately $150.00 including labour and material, in addition to material ordered in your letter file 2-11-3, of 26th November, addressed to Andrew Sheret Ltd.

Re: Bella Coola School

As the Department is already aware, this Office has advised against any building programme at Bella Coola to improve our most inadequate school facilities at that point, because of the possibility of increasing the number of native children admitted to the Provincial School. I am now informed by Mr. Superintendent Pruden that Ocean Falls School District, under whose jurisdiction the Bella Coola School comes, is prepared to consider a proposal for a joint building programme. Before making any survey or proceeding with the preparation of any plans the School District would like to have assurance that our Department is interested in their proposal and would assume its share of the capital cost, if a survey indicates that the proposal is feasible.

The Bella Coola Indian Day School is at present housed in two buildings, one of which is a fairly satisfactory school constructed about ten years ago. The second building is rented from the Bella Coola Band and is quite inadequate in every respect. These two buildings house at present approximately 70 children in grades 1 to 5. The existing Provincial School is not in excess of one-half mile from the farthest Indian pupil.

It is Inspector Davey's suggestion that we retain the satisfactory building for pre-primary purposes and that all of the school age population be admitted to the Provincial School. Mr. Davey has not made a survey of the Bella Coola situation but has made this suggestion so that he may have the Department's reaction before proceeding with a comprehensive survey.

I feel that the proposal for the admission of all the school age
Children to the Provincial School is of sufficient importance to warrant the transfer of funds from some project in our proposed building programme, since no provision has been made for a contribution to the capital cost of a combined school.

I might add that the Indians at Bella Coola all have protestant affiliation.

I shall appreciate receiving the Department's decision as to whether or not they are prepared to agree in principle to the admission of the Indian children to the Provincial school and the making of a contribution towards the capital cost of this building.

W.S. Arneil,
Indian Commissioner for B.C.

Memorandum:

ACTING DEPUTY MINISTER

Bella Bella, B.C. - Proposed Joint School

The Indian Commissioner for British Columbia has previously advised against any new Indian school building program at Bella Bella because of the possibility of increasing the number of native children admitted to the provincial school.

Inspector Davey has been carrying on negotiations with the Ocean Falls School District, under whose jurisdiction the Bella Coola Provincial School comes.

The Bella Coola Indian Day School is at present housed in two buildings, one of which is a fairly satisfactory school, constructed about ten years ago. A second building is rented from the Bella Coola Band and is quite inadequate in every respect. These two buildings house at present approximately 70 children in grades one to five. The existing provincial school is about a half mile away from the farthest Indian pupil.

It is Inspector Davey's recommendation that we retain the satisfactory building for kindergarten and primary purposes and that all of the school age population be admitted to the provincial school. This means that all the kindergarten and primary children will receive an education in basic English at our own school and then be sent to the provincial school.

I now attach a memorandum from Inspector Davey with regard to this proposed joint school. You will note it is
impossible at the present time to secure an accurate estimate of the cost to the Department of this new school.

It is recommended that this information be placed before Colonel Fortier upon his return so that he can give the matter consideration and advise whether we should proceed with the negotiations.

Acting Director.

Endl.
AIRMAIL

Indian Affairs Branch,
Department of Citizenship & Immigration,
Ottawa, Ontario.

Re: Bella Coola Indian Day Schools

Superintendent Pruden has requested authority for an expenditure of $60 for labor for painting the two classroom floors in the above-mentioned school buildings. He has secured a labor tender from an Indian, George Nelson, and states that an accountable advance will not be required.

He has not forwarded a copy of Mr. Nelson's tender, but I would recommend that he be authorized to have the work proceeded with on the understanding that the written tender will be forwarded so that a purchase order may be issued.

W.S. Arneil,
Indian Commissioner for B.C.

Dear Miss Bray:

Your letter of the 20th ultimo addressed to the Department of National Health and Welfare has been forwarded for my attention.

The matter of teaching boys boxing is very controversial and the modern trend in physical education, in school at least, is against such sports in so far as training for actual bouts and competitions. There are those teachers of physical education who hold that a scientific course in the noble art of self-defence is beneficial to the child. For your information I have written to the eminent authority on physiology, Dr. Arthur Steinhouse, whose paper on boxing I shall be glad to forward to you as soon as I receive it. However, your problem, as I understand it, is one with regard to your children boxing outside school hours, a matter which you can hardly control unless of course the children are hurt so much that it affects their academic standing or impairs their health.

In regard to the competency of the boxing instructor, there are of course several opinions on that question. If he is teaching physical education, the training would certainly be of benefit to the child, but if he is merely a boxing coach, he may be a successful one but there is no guarantee that the child will benefit.
The whole question of health teaching and physical education for the Indian population is under revision right now and I would suggest that before any action is taken on this matter you might discuss it more fully with me when I arrive in British Columbia some time this spring.

Yours very sincerely,

Ian Eisenhardt,
Supervisor of Physical Education & Recreation.

Sir,

When the Royal Indian Commission visited this Agency they took up the School matter on each of the Reserves and when they were holding their meeting with the Boothroyd Indians they were asked by the Indians if they could have a day School on the Reserve, and were promised that this matter would receive favorable attention from the Department.

I visited the Reserve yesterday, and examined the School, which will answer the purpose very well, I then held a meeting with the Indians, who are most anxious to get the School started, they have at least thirty children that should be at School, which they promised they would send.

I explained to them that we always had great difficulty in keeping the attendance of these day Schools up, but they promised me that they would take a petition round to all the parents and get them to sign that they would keep the children at School regularly.

As the Indians are so anxious to get their children taught, and have gone to the expense and trouble in building the School, I would strongly recommend that the Department sanctions their wish and supplies them with a Teacher.

As this School will be at a very out of the way place and the Teacher will have to live there, and cook for herself, I think that the salary should be set at $60.00 per month the same as the Shulus School.

Trusting that the Department will give this their earliest and favorable consideration.

I have the honor to be,

Your obedient servant.

Sir,

I have received a letter from Mr. Graham, Indian Agent, Lytton, enclosing copy of letter which he wrote the Department with reference to establishing an Indian day school on the Boothroyd reserve of that Agency.

It seems to me that in view of the large number of children (30) on that reserve that might attend and that the Indians seem so thoroughly interested in the matter, there is every encouragement to give them what they ask.

I know there is a prejudice in certain quarters against Indian day schools, and I note that my predecessor was not in favour of them (Report 1913, page 508). That there are some good reasons for the disapproval I can readily see, but nevertheless I can also see a very wide field for usefulness in them when the spirit exists to give them a fair trial, and in this case it does seem to exist.

As for the teacher recommended by the Agent, I have every confidence in the capabilities of Miss Blackford whose work in the day school at Lytton interested

Assistant Deputy and Secretary
me very much. If any teacher can secure regular attendance and retain the interest of the pupils it is she. She has excellent control and marked ability to impart instruction. Besides, she has the advantage of speaking the Thompson language fluently and is most useful as interpreter. In fact it always seemed to me unfortunate that her services should have been lost to the Department in its work of Indian education.

I have no hesitation in adding my recommendation that the Indians of the Boothroyd reserve be given the school.

I have the honour to be,

Sir,

Dear Sir,

I would like to suggest that the summer holidays of the Boothroyd Indian Day School be curtailed by two weeks, and these be added to the winter holidays.

My reason for suggesting this is that the Indians are inclined to forget what they learnt, and then it is much easier for them to come to school during the summer weather.

The parents will have finished their hay-making and the children will be doing nothing, and will be therefore better employed at School.

If the two weeks taken off the summer holidays were added to the winter holidays it will extend them a little over the bad weather when the snow is so deep and making it difficult for the children to walk the long distances some of them have to come.

I will be obliged if you will place this matter before the Department.

Sir,

Miss L. Blachford, the Teacher at the Boothroyd Indian Day School, has written me asking if the Department would consider an advance of $500.00 on her salary, which she would pay back in three years, at 6% interest.

She needs this money to help in building another home, and purchasing enough furniture to live in it. Miss Blachford lost practically everything she possessed in the fire last September. She took years planning and saving to build her house and to furnish it, and when she was away on her vacation last fall it was burned at the same time so much of Lytton was destroyed. If she had been at home she could have saved a good portion of her furniture, but with such a close burning and everybody trying to save their own property, hers was absolutely cleaned up. She had some insurance but not sufficient to build again, as the rate of insurance is high in Lytton, too high for her to be able to afford more insurance.

She thinks if she could get this loan she could pay it back at the rate of $200.00 a year, one hundred on her June cheque and one hundred from her December quarter cheque, each year for the three years, together with interest at 6%.

I advised her that I would place the matter before you although I could not give her any encouragement that she would get it.

Lumber is a way down in price at present and it would take much less to build right now than it may later on, which is why she would like to have a loan. If possible, I would like to see her get this help, or there might be some other way you could assist her.

I have the honor to be,
Sir,

Dear Sir:

May I refer to your favourable consideration, the case of Mrs. W. Raison, who is teaching at the Boothroyd School. There she is doing very excellent work with the Indian children, and if she left the School, we might have difficulty in replacing her and the School would probably close down.

She is now contemplating marriage with a man who is employed at an airport two miles away. She desires to continue teaching at the School, and, when married, would live at the School house during the week and spend the week ends at the airport house, where her husband would be compelled to live.

We have been given to understand that it is the rule of the Indian Department that married teachers should not be employed to teach in the Indian Schools. If this is indeed so, we would like to suggest that in the case of Mrs. Raison, who is indeed an excellent teacher, and under the present war conditions of a scarcity of teachers, that an exception to this rule should be made and that Mrs. Raison should be allowed to continue teaching in the Boothroyd School.

Dear Mr. Strang:

I have just received my Inspector's report on his visit to the above School last Friday March 17th.

There is one sentence to which I would like to draw your attention: "No cooking in being taught". "I consider this regrettable". I feel that this remark deserves some explanation.

The girls of this School have always been taught cooking until this year. At present, only two have not done any actual cooking because I feel they are too young, being only ten years old and in the junior grades, they have time yet to do what cooking is expected of them.

I have taken up fully, every health and nutrition and various projects with the boys and girls in an indirect way every day. They enjoy these talks and when filling in their daily health books for the Junior Red Cross I find that they are living very well. When visiting their homes I find that they are drinking milk from cows instead of from cans, eating lots of vegetables and fruit, both canned and raw apples, and fresh laid eggs as they all keep hens, fish and plenty of bread, bacon and stews etc.

I can assure you a day in our School is a busy one - not a moment is lost from the time the Union Jack is hoisted in the morning at 8:45 A.M. until taken down at 4 P.M. As closely as possible I follow the B.C. Course of Study. The children love their School, keep it clean, and together we all keep everything in repair.

I hope I have explained to you as I am afraid the above sentence might cause a little misunderstanding which I would not like to happen as my work in the School is conscientiously carried out.

Yours truly,

"Winnifred E. Raison"

I beg to acknowledge receipt of Departmental letter of the 29th ultimo with reference to the small number of children attending to the Boothroyd Indian Day School. Sir:

I am directed to acknowledge receipt of your letter of the 28th ultimo, with reference to payments made to Miss Lilly Blackford, teacher of the Boothroyd Indian Day School.

Teachers of Indian day schools are paid on the basis of ten teaching months in the academic year, which begins on September 1st each year and ends on the following June 30th.

Instead of taking two months' holidays during July and August, 1932, the teacher was authorized, owing to local conditions, to take one month's holidays during the March quarter of that year (see special notation on March quarter voucher) and one month's holidays in the September quarter. The following statement will, no doubt, explain the matter plainly to you:

7. SCHOOLS:

I visited the Day School at Boston Bar, under the teacher, Miss Blatchford, on the 20th June. There were 19 children in the school at the time of my visit, out of a roll of 21. I found the children in this school speaking up well, and seemed alert and intelligent. Both the higher and lower grades read very well and seemed to understand what they were reading. The children also gave me a demonstration in arithmetic which was quite good. I think this little school is a credit to Miss Blatchford. A new school house is very badly wanted. I should take it to be a very old place. The foundations have gone, and so has the floor. I do not think, therefore, that it is worth patching up. I might also add that Miss Blatchford informs me that there are three additional pupils who will be ready for her in the fall.

Dear Sir:

I would respectfully recommend that authority be granted for the following expenditure in repairing and assuring a more steady supply of water for the Boothroyd Indian Day School.

The following is needed: 558 feet of galvanized iron pipe at $3 cents per foot, 1 faucet, $1.10, and one stop and waste cock, $1.10.

Groceries for Indians whilst working at putting this in, would be $10.00.

This school remains in session throughout July and August, and there is at present no water, so I would strongly recommend this work be done.

Groceries for Indians whilst working at putting this in, would be $10.00.

The Indians are willing to supply the labor and only require a lunch being furnished, as many will come several miles to work.

The present pipe is all broken and burst from freezing last winter; the road construction also apparently having left the pipe exposed. The present supply of water dries up in July and August, and it is desired to supplement the supply from another spring close by.

This school remains in session throughout July and August, and there is at present no water, so I would strongly recommend this work be done.

Your obedient servant,

[A. H. Barber]
Indian Agent.

General Remarks:

The following Crown School Single Desks are now most urgently needed, far more so in my opinion than in any other school in British Columbia.

The present desks are double, so old that we do not know just where they came from, and tied up with string and wire. The teacher's chair is just as useless.

To aid various officials of the Department I am listing the actual desks required:

Crown School Single made in Vancouver:
No. 4 1 only Front 2 Desk Sections 1 only Rear
No. 2 2 only Fronts 2 Desk Sections 2 only Rears
No. 2 1 only Front 2 Desk Sections 1 only Rear

In addition one only teacher's chair.

A new school, to include a schoolroom to take up to thirty children, a teacher's kitchen, bed room, and living room, and a small room to be used as a store for Departmental Drugs and Dispensary, is so urgently necessary that it is quite impossible for me to urge its construction in the proper manner without the use of words which the Department may consider exaggerated. May I suggest reference to previous reports.

Whether a new school is built this next summer or not may I ask that the desks recommended above be provided. These desks should then be fixed in four short rows on the usual strips of wood. Accommodation will then be provided for the sixteen children likely to attend here in the near future, provided the school itself does not fall down. It will be remembered that the present school was never intended for such a use when erected. The views of the Indians expressed to me last year after my inspection of the school were given on Page 4 of my report forwarded on March 22nd 1937.

Lytton, B.C.

Indian Affairs. (RG 10, Volume 6386, File 804-5, part 2)
In my last report I urged the erection of a new school here. Such a school should contain a shoolroom to take up to thirty children, a vocational room which need not be large, a small room to be used as a store for Departmental drugs and a dispensary, and sufficient accommodation for a teacher and friend. This latter might well consist of a combined kitchen and living room, a bath room, and two small bed rooms.

It is impossible to exaggerate the importance of such a school at this point. The Indians are not anxious to send their children to St. George's Indian Residential School, and with a well equipped school here there would be no need to send any but the exceptional child to Lytton.

Many hundreds of American visitors to B.C. pass the present school yearly as it is located in the Fraser canyon and only a few yards from the main highway.

There are at the moment several buildings of a temporary nature on the Boothroyd emergency aerodrome or landing field. I am informed that these buildings will not be required. They were erected to house those who cleared the field. Some of the buildings are so constructed that they can easily be taken apart and moved. This aerodrome is within three miles of our Indian school.

May I suggest that the Department of National Defence be approached with a view to our being given the material from the unwanted buildings.

With such material and sufficient funds to pay for removal to the school site and reerection, it would not be difficult for the Indian Agent to arrange for local Indian labour to be paid for at a fair rate. Some large windows would be required. The Indians could do the work in connection with the erection of a school if supervised by one good carpenter, "white". I do not believe that such a school would cost in excess of say three thousand dollars.

The material which I understand is available at the neighbouring aerodrome might under certain conditions be used in the erection of an Indian school. I have seen the aerodrome only from the road. There appear to be a number of hutments. I know that it will be difficult to obtain funds to dismantle any huts which we may be given, transport the material to the Boothroyd school site, and re-erect as a school. Some large windows would also be required. I believe however that it is my duty to bring to the attention of the Department the possibility of having a new school at Boothroyd at little more than the cost of the Indian labour and the wages of possibly one "white" carpenter to oversee the work.
There is no need for an expensive school such as that lately erected at Port Simpson, just a simple school building with accommodation for a resident teacher and possibly a small vocational room and a dispensary is all that is required.

Should such a school as I have described be approved, the present small water tank located on the hill at the back of the school and fed by a small stream might well be greatly enlarged. No doubt one of the engineers could make the necessary survey report when again in that neighbourhood.

Any new tank should be sufficiently large to provide for the irrigation of the school garden by means of a garden hose, and to make sufficient water available in case of a small bush fire to protect the school buildings.

In forwarding the Inspector's Report, the Indian Commissioner MacKay writes as follows:

The buildings referred to by the Inspector in the paragraph "General Remarks" on page 3, are located at the Boothroyd emergency landing field, a few miles west of the Boothroyd Indian Day School. The buildings were used to house the men working in connection with the preparation and clearing of the emergency landing field, and are in good condition.

The Department might make enquiries regarding these buildings and, if they are no longer required in connection with the aeroplane field, they should, if possible, be secured for the Indians so they can be dismantled and the material used for improving Indian dwellings and also in the construction of a new school at Boothroyd should same be approved.
I found the pupils here, too, under Miss Blatchford, very busy preparing work for exhibit. Some very creditable work had been prepared. As they were so busy in this way, I had no opportunity to hear or see them at school work proper.

This school building badly wants repair; unless a new building is contemplated immediately. Some $600.00 could probably cover the cost of this. One thing that should be forwarded immediately is a chair for the teacher, Miss Blatchford. The awful old one she has got now, is impossible to use further.

I found, too that the children under her direction had planted a very creditable garden. They were all clean, neat, well dressed and appeared happy. There always seems to be a very happy atmosphere at this small day school.

Yours truly,

(Geo. S. Pragnell)
Inspector of Indian Agencies.
Memorandum:

MR. W. M. BAILEY:

The Boothroyd Indian Day School is located on the Boothroyd Indian Reserve, which borders the highway through the Fraser canyon. It is approximately 20 miles west of Lytton, B. C. Indian Commissioner MacKay, Vancouver, B. C., has advised us that there are a number of empty buildings at the Boothroyd emergency landing field, a few miles west of the Boothroyd Indian Day School. These buildings were erected by the Department of National Defence to house the foreman working in connection with the preparing and clearing of the emergency landing field and are in good condition. At the present time they are not in use.

Commissioner MacKay believes that, if we could secure these buildings, they could easily be moved to the Boothroyd reserve and used for the erection of a new school, which is badly needed, and also for repairing the houses of the Indians on the Boothroyd reserve.

I should appreciate it if you would take up the matter with the Salvage Officer and advise me if there is any likelihood of our being able to secure the buildings mentioned.

Dear Sir:

I desire to refer to your letter of the 3rd ultimo also your letter of November 25 enclosing Inspector Barry's report on his inspection of the Boothroyd Indian day school.

Please let me know if the material that has been salvaged from the landing field is sufficient to erect a new school. If not you should let me have detailed information regarding any additional material required provided its total cost would be over $500.00. If the cost would be under that amount it will only be necessary for you to advise me to that effect as in view of the recent change in purchasing regulations you could be authorized to make local purchase.

Would you propose to provide a basement as well as class room and living accommodation for the teacher?

Do you consider that the school could be built economically by day labour and, if so, an estimate of the cost of the labour would be appreciated.

I am not certain that funds can be provided from the current year's appropriation but I should like to have your reply before the end of the current month as it is possible that the funds could be secured before the end of March. In the event of funds being available could the erection of this building be commenced immediately?

LYTTON, B.C., January 18, 1939.

Dear Sir:-

Relative to your letter of January 11th, file #15/7/7517 with copy of Departmental letter enclosed, regarding the proposed new school at Boothroyd, I here-with enclose a rough plan together with a list of material required in excess of lumber from the Landing Field, and approximate prices thereof, with cost of supervision and Indian labour, amounting to $1,878.80. These figures were quoted by Mr. Dawson Claperton, carpenter of Lytton, who drew up the plans. Mr. Claperton states that he would undertake to construct the building for the sum of $920.00 for labour providing the Indians would take down the old school building and excavate the basement for the new school. This, of course, would cut out the $800.00 shown on the list for supervision and Indian labour.

I had a talk with the Indians and endeavoured to have them give their labour gratis but they refused and said they wouldn't work for less than $1.50 per day. The school could be built by Indian labour but I believe it would be cheaper in the end to have it constructed by a qualified white carpenter.

A full-size basement would be an advantage as apart from space for the heating system it would be an ideal place for the children to play during inclement weather. A dirt floor would be quite alright. I am probably get the Indians to dismantle the old school building and excavate for the new school, for the use of lumber from the old school. The basement would not be hard to excavate as the ground is chiefly sand and gravel.

Installation of a furnace would be extra but need not cost more than $75.00 as I would suggest installing an old time "drum heater" incased in concrete and brick with a steel top carrying the hot air pipes, with the cold air pipes let in near the base. I have seen such a heater installed and it has proved very effective. I am sure one would answer the purpose in this case.

The erection of the school could start immediately providing the present weather conditions continue.

Your obedient servant,

A. Strang,
Indian Agent.

D.M. MacKay, Esq.,
Indian Commissioner for B.C.,
Vancouver, B. C.

Dear Sir:

I am in receipt of your letter of the 2nd instant with reference to the expenditure that will be necessary to replace the Boothroyd Indian day school.

Inspector Barry's report of his inspection of the Boothroyd Indian day school on June 14, 1938, read, in part, as follows:

"I believe, however, that it is my duty to bring to the attention of the Department the possibility of having a new school at Boothroyd at little more than the cost of Indian labour and the wages of possibly one white carpenter to oversee the work."

With the above in mind, and the further fact that we had secured the lumber from the aerodrome, I wrote to you on the 3rd ultimo. However, it is noted from your recent letter that the lumber secured from the aerodrome was only of minor value and that materials amounting to approximately $1000.00 would be required. It is further noted that you estimate the total cost of the building at approximately $3000.00.

At the present time I am not in a position to state whether or not this amount of money will be available in the appropriation for the fiscal year 1939-40. However, the matter will be kept in mind and if funds can be secured you will be later advised.

Yours truly,

Major D. M. MacKay,
Indian Commissioner,
P.O. Box 70,
Vancouver, B.C.

R. A. Hoey,
Supt. of Welfare & Training.
Dear Sir:

Re Your File 165-26-5.

I wish to refer to Mr. Hoey's letter of January 23rd regarding the proposed new Day School at Boothroyd. In this connection I have now before me a report from Mr. Indian Agent Strang giving an estimate of $1878.80 for materials and labor required to build a school along the lines of a sketch submitted by him and using the salvaged materials from the Boothroyd Landing Field. Should a white carpenter be employed to build the school, the cost, from the information supplied by Mr. Strang, would be $2058. I am forwarding herewith a copy of Mr. Strang's letter together with the sketch referred to.

The sketch and information supplied by the Agent were discussed with Inspector Barry who considers that a school, but with full basement, along the lines of the Provincial Day School built at Sechelt, a plan of which was forwarded to you with my letter of December 25th, file 15/3/7339, would be more suitable than the building proposed by Mr. Strang.

The materials salvaged from the landing field are mostly rough, undressed pieces of fir lumber, six light sash, usually used in small cabins, barns and casements, and plain V-joint fir doors. The total value of what is available for the school would not exceed $200 and could be used for the framework of the building. Cement, nails, window and door frames, flooring, outside dressed lumber, shingles and a limited quantity of undressed lumber are required to build a new school. Such a school should be large enough for 30 pupils and might be laid out along the lines suggested by Capt. Barry on page 3 of his report on his inspection of the Boothroyd School, dated November 3, 1938.

The Secretary,
Indian Affairs Branch,
Department of Mines and Resources,
Ottawa, Ont.

My . . . .
My opinion is that the plan of the Provincial School at Sechelt would, with some slight changes, meet our requirements at Boothroyd. A full basement with cement floor and the usual wood burning furnace should be provided. I do not agree with Mr. Strang that a dirt floor in the basement would be suitable, especially in view of the character of the ground on which the building would be erected. As a large part of the basement would be above the ground level, provision could be made therein for a vocational training room and a small dispensary, or using the Sechelt School plan, the space provided for wood and store could be used for vocational training and a dispensary, and a section of the basement set aside for wood and store-room purposes.

I should imagine that the costs of a building along the lines of the Sechelt School with cement basement and furnace would be around £3000 and in view of this I feel that the safest and probably the most economical course to pursue would be to have plans prepared along the lines of the Sechelt Day School, with the suggested changes, and call for tenders for the building in the usual way. The value of the materials available from the landing field is small in comparison with the estimated cost of the proposed school. My dear Bishop Wells:

I am returning herewith certain correspondence relating to the construction of an Indian day school at Boothroyd, left at my office by Your Lordship a few days ago.

It would appear that the Indian Affairs Branch secured from the Boothroyd aerodrome about 30,000 feet of lumber, a certain amount of which was suitable for the construction of a school building. In view of this fact, the Indian Commissioner for British Columbia, Major D. M. MacKay, was requested to investigate the educational facilities at Boothroyd and report to the Department.

The records indicate that Reverend A. R. Lett, Principal of the St. George's Indian Residential School, wrote to the Department on February 27, 1939, intimating that in his judgment a thorough survey of local conditions at Boothroyd should be made before the school was rebuilt on the old site. Mr. Lett's letter read in part as follows:

"Before action is taken, a survey should be made with a view to placing the new school on a reserve where it could reach the greatest number of children. I am sure a better location could be found, and if money and time is to be spent it should be used to the greatest advantage."

Immediately -

Right Reverend G. A. Wells, C.M.G., M.A., D.D.,
Bishop of Cariboo,
Kamloops, British Columbia.
Immediately following the receipt of this communication from Mr. Lett, the Indian Commissioner was asked to have Captain Barry, Inspector of Indian Schools, make a survey of the Boothroyd district. I regret to state, however, that Mr. Barry's report has not yet reached the Department. No provision was made in the 1939-40 estimates for the amount of money necessary to rebuild the school. It is our intention, however, just as soon as the report of the survey reaches us, to make provision for the rebuilding of this school in the estimates of next year.

It is in my judgment somewhat regrettable that this delay has occurred in the construction of the building. In view of Mr. Lett's letter, however, the officials felt that a survey was necessary before a final decision could be made.

Before Day Schools are recommended, Reserves from which the pupils are to be drawn are examined and a careful survey made of the children available for such a school. Only one Day School has been erected in a new field since I have been in the service, viz., the one at Pemberton. The attendance at present here is 37. Dear Major MacKay:

Acting on your instructions I carried out a school survey of the Boothroyd Band, Lytton Agency, in the intervals of other work during the period April 18th to 21st inclusive.

The result of my investigations has been to prove that the statements of the Reverend A.R. Lett, Principal of the St George's Residential School, Lytton, made to the Department and quoted to you by Mr Hoey have no possible foundation in fact. Mr Lett discussed his letter to the Department with me and even showed me a copy though he could not explain why he had not sent a copy to you at the time he sent the original to the Department.

In general Mr Lett based his suggestions on a change in policy by which the St George's School should be reserved for a limited number of Junior and Senior High School pupils and the rest of the present pupils sent back to such places as Shulus in the Nicola Agency.

I explained to Mr Lett that he was now very short of pupils and that to send the Lytton, Shulus, Boothroyd and other children home would empty his school. He remarked that that would not matter, but pointed out that we had plenty of room in the present Shulus Indian Day School, but he talked quite foolishly of taking out the Roman Catholic Children from the Kamloops Residential School and sending those belonging to Shulus back to that school. It wasof little use to speak to Mr Lett about such matters as he appears to me to be rapidly becoming irresponsible and at certain times during my inspection of the St George's School spoke about educational matters in a most foolish manner.

Mr Lett would appear to wish to do everything to prevent the erection of a new school at or near Boothroyd. He and the teacher there Miss Blackford did not agree about many things, and my own opinion is that Mr Lett is very much upset that she, an untrained Indian woman, should be obtaining obviously better results along several lines than he can obtain at St George's. I do not consider that any great importance should be placed on Mr Lett's opinions on a subject of which he knows very little. In any case the attached survey report will give you and the officials at Ottawa a fair picture of the actual condition of things at Boothroyd.

May I suggest that you ask Mr Indian Agent Strang for a short report on the Johnnie Andrew property mentioned in my report as highly suitable for the proposed new Boothroyd Indian Day School. The local Indians have promised Mr Strang to work on the school at $1.00 per day, and I hope that the school may be erected soon.

Yours very truly,

Gerald H. Barry,
Inspector of Indian Schools, B.C.

Purpose of Survey:

This survey with respect to the educational needs of the Indian children living on the various Boothroyd Indian Reserves in the Lytton Agency, or belonging to this Band and at the moment living away from these Reserves was undertaken in conjunction with my ordinary inspection duties in the Agency and thus involved the Department in no extra expense of any kind.

The general purpose of this investigation was to determine the necessity for an Indian Day School on the Boothroyd Reserves, and should it be found that such a school was in fact necessary to determine the very best location for such a school.

The more particular aim of the survey was to locate all Indian children belonging to the Boothroyd Band by an examination of the Agency records and through a visit to the St George's Indian Residential School, the Boothroyd Indian Day School, and the Indian homes where necessary.

Procedure Adopted:

The office work in regard to the examination of the census book of the Boothroyd Band and the making of the necessary extracts was undertaken in Lytton on April 18th, 19th and 20th in intervals of other work, while much of the information required for the Department was tabulated by Mr Sampson, the Agency Clerk.

Maps of the various Indian Reserves were also consulted, and it was found that information with regard to the actual Indian Reserves from which the majority of the children attending the Boothroyd Day School came previously supplied in Vancouver to the Indian Commissioner was in fact incorrect. I very much regret that through my carelessness in misfiling the Map Crown was this week at Inkahtasph the Indian Commissioner was informed that the majority of the children at the Boothroyd Indian Day School came from Boothroyd Indian Reserve No. 1 (Tsawwassen) to Boothroyd Indian Reserve No.5 (Sho-oak) from which Reserves as a matter of fact no children are drawn. The information given on subsequent pages is correct and shows that the pupils of the Boothroyd School come from Boothroyd Indian Reserves No.6 and No.6A a few miles north of the first mentioned Reserves.

Mr Indian Agent Strang accompanied me on a visit to the various Indian Reserves mentioned in my survey report, and gave me very valuable assistance throughout my investigation.

Where children are shown by the Agency records to be attending St. George's Indian Residential School the Residential School records were also consulted with the Reverend A.R.Lett, Principal of St. George's, and the fact of the children's actual residence at St George's School verified.

Miss L. Blachford, teacher at the Boothroyd Indian Day School gave me much assistance and verified the fact that the Reverend Mr Lett had visited his school for several years and was in no position to comment on the average attendance which is about 13 though Mr Lett stated that only about 7 children were ever at the school when he visited there.

Probable Attendance:

Should a new Indian day school be erected as is recommended below either on a site immediately adjoining the present Boothroyd Indian Day School as previously suggested, or on the site discovered during my present survey visit, the average attendance would in all probability continue to be around 85% of the total number of pupils available.

If my suggestions, made on Page 4, be followed there would be 22 children on the school roll and an average attendance of between 17 and 18.

There appear to be some 19 children now under school age. This would mean that some three little pupils would on the average be available yearly for the Primary Class and there would be no falling off in attendance for a number of years at least, but possibly an increase.

A school to accommodate thirty pupils would be required.

Provincial Schools:

There are no Provincial schools in this neighbourhood.

Religious Teaching:

The whole of the children mentioned in this survey report are members of the Anglican Church. It would probably be under the auspices of this Church that the proposed school to replace the present Boothroyd School would be administered.

Possible Site for School:

A satisfactory site would be that immediately to the WEST of the present school house. There is a hill on which the building might be placed. The present very small school garden could be used. Water is available by extension of about 100 feet of pipe line from the end of the present pipe. Source of water is a spring in hill near school. The present dam would need to be enlarged as previously recommended.

The location of the present school and the above site is on Indian Reserve No. 6 (Inkatsaph).

While this site which was by far the best available so far would do very well for a small school and residence I wish now for the first time to bring to your notice what I consider to be a far superior site, and one that would provide a safe playing field and good garden for the pupils.

I refer to a small parcel of land of perhaps two acres located on the same Inkatsaph or Inkitsaph Indian Reserve Boothroyd No. 6 but between one half and three quarters of a mile SOUTH of the present school. This land belongs to an Indian, Johnie Andrew, who has plenty of other land and does not appear to take much interest in this piece.

The land lies along the side of the main road but is approached by an overgrown piece of the old road parallel with the new road and thus protected for children from traffic.

There are the remains of an old garden, fruit trees and bushes, and the children could make a fine school garden here. The old log house has no roof and only a part of the floor. It would be no good as a school but could be used in the manner suggested below.
Water is available from the Inkitsaph Creek from which domestic water would have to be piped by a pipe of about one inch, while water for the garden could be led from the same creek in the old dug out irrigation ditch. The Indian Agent informs me that we have rights on the Inkitsaph or Inkahtsaph Creek flowing through this No.8 Reserve.

Mr Indian Agent Strang tells me that he has no doubt that the Department could secure this fine site for around the sum of $50.00. I may say that I consider that it would be well worth paying up to $100.00 for two acres here to include old buildings and fruit trees etc.

I requested Mr Strang to find out exactly how much the Indian owner, Johnnie Andrew, would be prepared to accept for any rights he may have in this parcel of ground.

**Type of School Needed:**

This question has been reported on previously. In brief the school should be for thirty pupils. There should be a kitchen living room adjoining the schoolroom so that the teacher can supervise the work of the Vocational Class and the academic work at the same time. Two small bed rooms, one for the teacher and one for the boy who helps with the garden and usual chores, a vocational room if possible and a small room for the Department's drugs, with accommodation in the basement for Manual Training, should meet the needs of this Band. Several of the above small rooms might be located in the basement. The whole house should probably be on one level with the exception of the cement or dirt court basement.

With regard to the provision of cement for either basement of foundations, or probably best a part cement and frame basement, I may say that there is a good cement mixer available in the Indian Agent's yard.

**Old Building on Proposed Site:**

There is a substantial one room log building, the logs being sized and shaped, on this site and located very near the main road. This building has no roof and would require a roof, floor, windows, and doors.

There is however plenty of rough material available from the old abandoned buildings to complete this house AFTER the school has been erected.

I believe that such a house as this finished in an attractive manner with a shake roof and some paint might be used as a sale room for Indian Arts and Crafts. It could be under the supervision of the teacher Miss Blanchford and articles made by the Indians either in school or by ex school children could be sold to the hundreds of tourists passing along this famous Fraser Valley Scenic Highway. Even baskets and other articles made at Lytton might be sold here, during the summer months. It will be remembered that this Boothroyd School does not take vacation in July and August as other schools do but in September and the winter to include the hop season and to allow for the bad snow of January.

**Recommendation:**

Regardless of any foolish remarks of the Principal of St George's Indian Residential School, I would very strongly recommend the erection of the new Boothroyd Indian Day School as previously suggested and on the new site proposed here.

Vancouver, B.C.

Gerald H. Berry,
Inspector of Indian Schools, B.C.

Years ago when the 5 Commissioners were here to investigate the question of Reserves and living conditions of the Indians.

This school was talked over with them. The Commissioners asked us. Why? Didn't we send our children to St. Georges at Lytton? Our late Chief Benedict told them that we didn't want to send them away from home and that we didn't like the way that some of the children acted towards their parents when they came home from school. But, if the Dept. would put up a school for us here on our Reserve, we'd gladly send our children to school.

After much talk it was agreed that the Indians put up a building and the Dept. would pay the teacher's salary. Both parties promised that this school would be kept going as long as there were pupils to attend.

Then Chief Benedict told the Commissioners that he'd like to have Miss L. Blachford appointed for our teacher. The Commissioners were pleased with this suggestion, they asked Miss Blachford if she'd accept the position, which she did, when they'd agreed on the salary and that we provide living quarters for her.

We put up the building at our own expense and labour. School was opened May 3rd 1915. Its been in use ever since. We've sent our children regularly though its been hard for some of us to furnish clothes - (especially shoes) and food for lunches.

The 2 rooms provided for the teacher are very small and we know its been hard work for her to carry on, teaching our girls to can salmon, fruit and cooking in such a small kitchen and living room.

We were very happy when we thought the Dept. had decided to give us a suitable building and we were very eager to begin the work. But, now we are disappointed to hear that the Dept. might not build as a report had been sent in that the attendance here wasn't up to standard nor were there sufficient children on the Reserve to warrant the expense of a new school.

We are sorry to hear about this report as it is not a true fact.
We have done our part in sending our children regularly. The only time a child is kept at home is on account of sickness or bad weather. There could be more children attending here if the children that have been taken to St. Georges, were allowed to return and if the Dept. would give some assistance to Day Scholars for as I have stated before, some of the parents couldn't afford the expense of clothes so they sent their children to St. Georges where they have everything supplied for them. We would be very grateful if you can persuade the Dept. to give us a new school. As its over 8 years now that we've had to repair and prop up the old foundation every spring.

The work done here is very good, this school won a 1st & a 3rd prize last year at the B.C. Indians Art & Handicraft Display in Vancouver, B. C. It also divided 1st prize money at the Kamloops Fair the year before.

Our children come home, help us and take an interest in our work, they respect their parents and are not so dissatisfied as some of the children that come home from a school where they've been living in what are called "luxuries" which our poor homes cannot give them.

We are sorry that our circumstances will not allow us to assist in building without pay as we did 24 years ago, as you know that we've not been able to obtain work either on the Highway nor the Railroads besides its getting harder each year to sell our farm products locally.

If we get the new school we'll see that our children attend regularly and I'm sure that if the Dept. can help the scholars we'll have no trouble in keeping up the attendance as we'll get more scholars from other reserves as I've often been told by Indians that they'd like to send their children here but couldn't afford the extra expense - though we have pupils attending now because their parents prefer our school.

I do hope Mr. Strang that you will do your best to get the school for us.

"Chief Wallace Bradley"
in behalf of The Boothroyd Band
Acting Chief "Paul Michell" witness
Ottawa, June 28, 1939.

Memorandum:

DEPUTY MINISTER

In preparing the special supplementary estimates for the current fiscal year an amount of $6000.00 was included for the erection of a new school on the Thunderchild Indian Reserve, Battleford Indian Agency, Province of Saskatchewan. Subsequent to the preparation of these estimates Inspector Robertson reported that he considered that the present school on the Thunderchild Reserve would meet the requirements for another few years.

The amount mentioned above is, therefore, available and I wish to bring to your attention the under-mentioned two items for which no funds were provided:

1. Fisher River Indian Day School,
   Fisher River Indian Agency,
   Province of Saskatchewan,
   Electoral District of Selkirk.

Approximate expenditure ...........................................$1300.00

Some months ago it was brought to our attention that the walls of this school were in very bad condition. The Surveys & Engineering Branch were requested to have one of their officers inspect the school and he reports that the walls are in very bad condition and estimates that it will cost $1226.90 to put the building in proper condition. For your information I may add that the building at Fisher River is a two-roomed school with teachers' residence attached and there is an enrolment of 73 pupils.
2. Boothroyd Indian Day School,
   Lytton Indian Agency,
   Province of British Columbia,
   Electoral District of Fraser Valley.

Approximate expenditure ...................... $4700.00

For some time past Rt. Rev. G.A. Wells, Anglican Bishop of Cariboo, has been urging the Department to provide a new school. Within the last week a report has been received from Indian Commissioner Mackay enclosing detailed information regarding the educational requirements on this Reserve. Commissioner Mackay recommends that if at all possible the present old school on the Boothroyd Reserve be replaced by a new one. A recent report from Inspector Barry indicates that there are 25 children of school age on this Reserve and that there are 19 additional children under school age but who will be attending school within the next few years.

As the repairs at the Fisher River school are urgently required, and as Indian Commissioner Mackay agrees with His Lordship Bishop Wells that a new school is required on the Boothroyd Indian Reserve, I should appreciate it if the Honourable the Minister would approve our expending at the two places mentioned above the amount of $6000.00 provided in the special supplementary estimates for the erection of a school on the Thunderchild Reserve. In the event of the Honourable the Minister granting his approval the work at Fisher River would be done under the supervision of the Surveys & Engineering Branch. The erection of the school on the Boothroyd Reserve would be done under the direction of Commissioner Mackay.

Dear Sir:

Re Boothroyd School (File 165/26/5).

Replying to your letter of the 28th ultimo advising that it has been found possible to proceed with the construction of an Indian Day School on Boothroyd Indian Reserve No. 6, I would advise that the plan that has been selected as providing the most economical construction for the accommodation required is shown on enclosed white print, being B.C. Provincial Department Public Works Plan No. 552, but some modification of the plan is required to meet the conditions imposed by the site available, chief of which is that the plan is to be reversed. As an extra bedroom is necessary, it is suggested that the lean-to should become an extension of the school proper and include small bedroom (7'6" x 10'0" would be large enough). Mr. Agent Strang thinks that a kitchen-living room would be satisfactory with a porch. As the school is to be built on a fairly steep side hill, the front entrance steps would have to be on the side opposite to the large classroom windows. The main classroom lights should face the river on the west. It is proposed to have a basement running the full length of the school and about 15' or 16' wide to accommodate small room for drugs and supplies. Owing to the slope of the site, very little excavation would be required, and this would be on the side with the main classroom.

windows. If it is decided to call for tenders, they could call for alternative constructions of concrete basement, floor and foundation as shown, or the building on concrete blocks with cedar posts and frame construction. There should also be provision for two outside latrines.

KAMLOOPS, B.C., July 8, 1939

My dear Mr. Hoey,

I thank you for your letter of June the 13th regarding the Boothroyd Indian School at Lytton, B.C. in the Diocese of Cariboo.

I have just returned from a visit and special service at the school where I discussed the question of a new school and the right site for it with Mr. Strang, the Indian Agent; Miss Blackford, the teacher; and the Indian Chiefs of the Boothroyd Band. I venture to give you my convictions on two points in connection with the matter.

1. Excellent work is being done by the Teacher from the moral, social, and educational standpoint for the Indians in spite of most inadequate facilities and delapidated building. There should be a new building there at the earliest possible convenience.

2. There is general agreement, and not the least doubt in my mind, that the present site is the most convenient for the Indians and is likely because of settlement possibilities for all time. With very little expenditure on levelling the land, and some care in placing the building, it will be found adequate and suitable. The Indian Chief's volunteered to help in preparing the site at once.

I feel that there is no need of saying to you that what I have done and am prepared to do in this matter is in no way interfering with your department or with the Agent at Lytton. My object is to help in every way I possibly can to support any movement that is made in the real interest of the Indian in this diocese.

With kind regards,

Yours most sincerely,

Mr. R.A. Hoey, B.A.,
Supt. Welfare & Training,
Indian Department,
Ottawa.

Dear Sir:

I enclose herewith application of Mr. Phillip McLean as foreman of construction of the proposed Boothroyd Indian Day School in the Lytton Agency. Mr. McLean was formerly manual training teacher at the Lytton Indian Residential School and in that capacity did some very excellent construction with Indian boys demonstrating his ability to handle Indians in this class of labour.

It is proposed to use Indian labour as far as possible in the construction of this school.

Mr. McLean is asking 75¢ per hour and I would recommend his appointment and advice of same by air mail if possible.

Yours faithfully,

Dear Sir:

Re New Indian Day School, Boothroyd.

I have to refer to Mr. Hoey's letter of August 11th, 1939, file 165-26-5, authorizing the construction of a new day school at Boothroyd.

While in the Lytton Agency a few days ago I visited Boothroyd and found construction so far advanced that in all probability the building will be completed and ready for use by March 31st. Some cement work, construction of cupboards and interior and exterior painting, remain to be done but as these are being attended to, the end of the month should see the work fully completed.

It will be recalled that E.R.1054 dated August 11th, 1939, in the amount of $4700 was set up for this project. This authorization included $1500 cash advance for labour.

An examination of the expenditures in connection with this construction indicates clearly that the school will be completed for $3100, leaving a balance of $1600 available for other purposes.

I may say that the school has been well built and should meet the requirements of the Indians in the Boothroyd section for many years. It is a 30' by 60' frame structure on cement foundation with one classroom and teacher's residence. The building is heated by a well installed wood burning hot air furnace. The basement has a full cement floor and is subdivided so as to provide for store room, fuel room and a large bright section which can be used for manual training. The existing water system has been extended into the building with a tap in the kitchen and one in the basement.

The Secretary,
Indian Affairs Branch,
Department of Mines and Resources,
Ottawa, Ont.
Mr. McLean was employed as carpenter foreman and with the exception of the installation of the furnace, which was carried out by a firm in Vancouver, Indian labour was provided.

It will in all probability be necessary for the Department to furnish the residence as the furniture used by the late Miss Blachford belonged to her.

I will arrange to have some camera snapshots of the new school taken for the Department when a good opportunity offers.

Yours faithfully,

D. M. MacKay,
Indian commissioner for B.C.

AGENT'S REPORT ON LYTTON AGENCY FOR MONTH OF MARCH 1940.

SCHOOLS

I am pleased to report that with the exception of another coat of paint on the outside of the building, which can be put on at some suitable time, the new Boothroyd school was completed this month. The building is very satisfactory and the laying of a cement floor in the basement is a decided asset as the basement is now an ideal place for manual training work for the boys. The Indians are very pleased with the building and I am sure it will encourage regular attendance at the school.

A. Strang.
Indian Agent.
Ottawa,
June 11, 1940.

AIR MAIL

Dear Sir:

I have your letter of the 7th instant in which you state that Mr. F.R. Shenstone has decided not to accept appointment as teacher of the Boothroyd Indian Day School and I note that you will advise later regarding the teacher who you recommend be appointed.

Re: Foothroyd Day School Building

The above-mentioned building has been unused for several years and according to advice recently received from Superintendent Hett, there is no prospect of sufficient pupils being available in the near future. We have been approached by Mr. Grant Starr, Dominion Government Engineer, who is working in the vicinity of Foothroyd, for permission to occupy the building as a residence for himself and his family.

Mr. Starr has offered to pay rental but after discussing the matter with him, I am of the opinion it would be preferable for us to permit him to occupy the building without charge, on the understanding that he will look after ordinary maintenance. I have in mind that the building has been unoccupied for some time, that some maintenance is no doubt necessary by now and that if the building is heated and occupied, it will not deteriorate as quickly as otherwise.

May I please have the Department's views in this matter.

Boothroyd Indian Day School

Reference your 165/6-2-804 of September 16

We are prepared to rent this school building to Mr. Starr, who, it is presumed, is an employee of the Department of Public Works. The terms are as follows:

(1) The classroom must be locked so that no damage will be done to the desks, etc.

(2) If Mr. Starr wishes to use the teacherage furniture, then the rental will be $30.00 per month.

(3) If he wishes to use his own furniture, the rental will be $20.00 per month. If the furniture is not used, then it must be stored in the classroom and locked.

(4) An inventory of the furniture in the school is to be made and forwarded here with a statement opposite each item concerning its condition.

While it is agreed that Mr. Starr will look after ordinary maintenance of the building, it is our practice to charge rental for these buildings so that there will be no complaints from the Indians.

Dear Sir:

Your communication in regard to my labours in connection with the day school at this place received in the mail yesterday, and hasten to reply to the same, especially when the non-success of the school of late is laid to my "neglect and indifference" as you state.

There is no doubt that for the last three years the school has been a failure as far as an educational factor among our Indians is concerned. I have been among these people nearly seven years; when I arrived here I found all work at a low ebb, church and day-school poorly attended, the yearly average of the school being 24 according to Blue Books.
After two years this average was increased to 1246 and our school continued to flourish until the winter of 1907-8, when our people received a visit from that well known Indian agitator Capatino Joe, who first started the controversy in B.C. re. Indian lands; he put him out of our mission village, and he took up his abode in another village near by taking the majority of our people with him. After Joe's advent conditions changed in our villages; our people are not allowed to work at the timber on their own reserves owing to the dispute between the B.C. and Ottawa governments over "land titles"; so they have to find work somewhere so the majority of them find it miles from home taking their families with them.

Starting in June our people find employment at the salmon-fishing working for a cannery some three miles distant from our school, the fishing lasts well into October; after this they are home for about 10 days, then away to different places to dry fish.
for their winters use, returning from Nov. 20th to Dec. 25th remaining in their villages till after Xmas; then there able-bodied people go trapping and logging taking their families with them.

| JUNE TO OCTOBER | NOVEMBER-DEC | JAN-MARCH | APRIL-MAY |
|-----------------|-------------|-----------|-----------|
| SALMON FISHING  | DRYING FISH | TRAPPING LOGGING | AT HOME |

Last September our people asked permission of the Department to exchange the timber on a portion of the reserve for a building suitable for their children to sleep and eat in during their parents' absence; this request was refused by the Department on account of the dispute between the B.C. government over "land titles." Our people earnestly desire their children to go to school, but cannot better their condition in that respect on account of existing conditions.

Personally I have done everything in my power to make our school a success, the chief cause of failure is the irregular attendance; this state of affairs is common all over this agency; on the 11th of this month I attended a meeting.
called by the Rev Hall of Alert Bay, to consider the prevailing conditions among the Indians in these parts; this meeting was attended by all Indian workers in this district and many native delegates. Mr. Hall stated that his church (English) had been losing ground for the last six years; only one of his day-schools having an regular attendance the home one at Alert Bay; our native delegate presented a petition to the Indian agent who presided at the meeting from all our people and myself asking that they might be allowed to remove the timber from 40 acres of the reserve near our village this season so that their people could find work at home and their children attend school; this was promised the support of our Indian agent; and together with several petitions of a similar nature from other villages received the endorsement of the meeting.

I have three villages under my charge, one 40 miles north—
and another on Vancouver Island some four miles away. Our mission-house is situated on Valdez Island, built on the Cape Mudge reserve property. When we have no school here I am constantly on the move; the society gave me a launch a few years ago so I could reach my people. The only other church working among these Indians is the Church of England who are doing a aggressive work in these parts. Our people are fully awake to the necessity of a school in this village and are determined to rally around their missionary and look after their children this coming year.

Causes of non-success of schools in past:
- nomadic conditions of the Indians,
- indifference of some parents,
- want of sympathy Government & Church,
- no support from Church Indian Missions in B.C.

Our hope for the future:
- In God,
- In the Indians,
- In the Good Lord Church,
- In ourselves

Excuse hurry in putting this together as our mail returns at once. Hoping to hear from you again.

I am sincerely yours,

Quathaski Cove
