Sir:-

Referring to your letter of 18th Feb'y regarding the regulations as to the number of hours that Indian Schools should be in session and asking if there is any reason why the Cape Mudge School should be exempt from the regulations I would inform you that with the exception of the difficulty in getting the children to attend there is no reason why any school in this agency should not follow the regulations. It is difficult enough to get the children to attend at 10 o'clock as they are lazy in the mornings.

I may state that in all the schools in the agency excepting the Industrial school there have only been two sessions of two hours each. In the Provincial Schools for white children the regulations call for the following hours of attendance:- In the mornings from 9 to 12 with 15 minutes intermission. In the Afternoons from 1 to 3.30 with ten minutes intermission. REPORT OF INSPECTOR CAIRNS ON THE CAPE MUDGE DAY SCHOOL.

Date of Inspection—September 27th, 1916.

School was closed at the time of my visit. Mr. Rebholz informed me that the people would not be home till about Nov. 1st. It will be seen that the school year is exceedingly short. So short that very little is accomplished.

The missionary does not like to send any pupils to an industrial school. Those who would go are the pupils who are somewhat interested in education. If six or eight of these were sent away to school, the problem of carrying on school becomes almost hopeless.

The attendance at many of the day schools is so irregular that little is accomplished. In my opinion the great majority of the day school pupils will be classed as illiterate when they reach manhood.

Walter Parker

Sir:

I am in receipt of a letter dated April 3rd, asking for a special report regarding the services of Mrs. F. Howard, teacher at the Cape Mudge Indian Day School.

Mrs. Howard is not a certified teacher, but has given very faithful work at the school. The great criticism that I have to her school methods is that it is too much kindergarten for pupils of the age that she has there. Apart from the school work, her services have been extremely valuable to the Indians occupying the Cape Mudge village and those who visit there. Her influence has always been for good amongst them, and she has gone round helping the women to keep their houses tidy and clean, and has been of very great assistance to them in that way.

Unfortunately, for some considerable time past there has been considerable friction between Mrs. Howard and the Rev. George Knox, the clergyman there, and this has interfered considerably with the results of her work. She has two daughters, one of whom is married and who lives with her husband in the house provided for the teacher. This has been the cause of a certain amount of friction, as some of the Indians object to son-in-law being there, while many of them are quite agreeable. As no complaints have ever been made to me on this matter, I do not take any part in it, as I realize that an Indian village is a very lonesome place for a white person, unless they have some of their own kind with whom they can associate.

Your obedient servant,

(W.M. Halliday)

Dear Sir:

A Committee of our men including the Chiefs' met last night to discuss our school situation, and make recommendations to you which we feel very necessary for the benefit of our children and the improvement of our Village.

We notice the rapid changes which are taking place, and the advancements which are being made these days around us, it is so also on our Reserve at Cape Mudge.

Years ago when Mr. Walker taught here, it was very hard to get the children to attend school, especially the boys; but Mr. Walker persevered and worked hard and always took a deep interest in the scholars, and the good results are quite visible today.

However the situation has greatly changed, as our people have become more civilized, and want to go forward and take their place in life. For today our children want to go to school, and are there.

But we are sorry to have to say our children are almost at a stand still. Mrs. Howard the teacher, when she started here about ten years ago worked hard for a while, but now for some years, we notice she takes very little interest in our children and none of them are getting on as they should. There has been no school Inspector here for about two and a half years to see how things have been run. We also note the school is not being held proper hours.

So we are asking you to please see that we get a change of teacher, by the beginning of next fall term, but sooner if at all possible. A Certificate teacher, who is up to date, who can lead our children along in the modern way with the up to date system. We trust you will please take the necessary action in order to comply with our reasonable request, for the sake and progress of our Village.

Hoping to hear from you at your earliest convenience, we remain

Yours sincerely

Chief "Billy Assu"
Chief "Johnnie Chickite"

Dear Sir:

Enclosed please find a letter which a Committee of our Indian men wished me to dictate for them.

I might say the school situation here has been very unsatisfactory for some years, the children are not getting either the time or attention or proper training they should.

I reported the matter last spring at our Conference, and our B.C. Committee saw the necessity of a change, and have asked for it, and no doubt this would have taken place, but relatives were involved.

Mrs. Howard never having had any training, never has properly taught the different grades. We know this by having sent our own girl for a time, she both neglected her studies and health.

I also find that she sent some pupils up to Sardis School supposed to be in the fifth grade, but when they got into a standard school had to drop back some of them to the second grade. I am enclosing a photo, the two girls on the outsides have been going to this school for nearly seven years; they are in the fourth grade, but in many things they would have to drop back to the second.

I enjoy the Indians very much and with their advancement in civilization they need more than an old form of Kindergarten school. They would go ahead if they had a chance.

I appreciate very much Mr. Ditchburn what you have done to help these people since I came here about two and a half years ago; and I trust you will help to improve the present situation at an early date.

Will be glad to hear from you with any suggestions you may have to offer for the betterment of things here.

Yours faithfully,

"Geo. Knox."

Dear Mr. Ditchburn:

Re your letter #15/6/20015, dated January 20th, 1931.

In conversation with Missionaries, Teachers and Officials of the Department, I have referred to situations of a similar nature, to which you specially refer in connection with Cape Mudge, and have remarked, casually and in general terms, that sometimes children coming from an ungraded day school have to be demoted.

In this connection you refer to Cape Mudge "pupils in Grade V at Coqualeetza when sent to Coqualeetza had to drop back to Grade II." When pupils have come from Cape Mudge School to Coqualeetza we have had to take the work of the pupil or the parent as to standing until they were tried out and properly standardized according to grade. In looking up the records I find the case of one boy who was put in Grade V and a girl who was placed in Grade IV. These on the office copy of the register, were crossed out and they were reduced and put in their proper rank which was Grade II. When questioned, new pupils sometimes state they are in a higher grade than they are entitled to, but that is not a reflection on nor a fault of the school teacher from whom they come. I have had no correspondence with the teach in question in regard to the grades but can frankly say that pupils coming from her school have not exaggerated their grade standing more than from other schools. I have had, at different times, pupils from the North who were supposedly ready to take the Eighth Grade for the Entrance examinations -- three within the last four years, who were good Sixth Grade pupils instead of Eighth Grade.

Ungraded day schools on Indian Reserves work at great disability. The children are often away with their parents for long periods, and upon returning to the school go into the Grade which they left. This spasmodic system discourages them as they have to remain for too long a period in the same grade, being outdistanced by those of the same age who commenced school at the same time but who have been able to attend regularly. I would not be surprised under such conditions a teacher might be tempted to stint his effort by promise of advancement. The pupilage from Cape Mudge is on the whole not different from the pupilage of any other Reserve.

Trusting this explanation is satisfactory, and that it will not be necessary to bring my name into the affair as I am on friendly terms with both Missionary and Teacher.

Yours very truly,

(Sgd) G. H. Raley,
principal.

It has been reported to me that the United Church are planning on making a change of teachers at Cape Mudge for the Day School there, in which a Minister-Teacher is to be appointed for this position. I am strongly opposed to this as Miss Hill's services have always been very satisfactory and in view of so much opposition to the contemplated change coming from the Indians and everyone in general, I am making a special report to the Department expressing my views opposing any change being made, and I would kindly ask the Department to not agree to any change until all the particulars are before them.

June 11, 1936.

Sir,

In my Monthly Report for May I mentioned the United Church was contemplating requesting the Department for a change of teachers at Cape Mudge School, and I suggested to the Department that no action be taken until the matter could be properly placed before them by this office.

Since then I have received a communication from the Cape Mudge Indians in which they are strenuously objecting to Miss Hill's services being discontinued, more particularly because the Church have suggested to them that a Minister-Teacher take her place, so that the minister would be available to hold Church services at Cape Mudge, Campbell River and Quathiaski Cove.

I am also informed by ministers who attended the United Church Conference recently held in Vancouver that the Church had in mind even extending the duties of the minister by placing a boat at his disposal at Quathiaski Cove so that he could serve a wider field than the places mentioned above.

First, I am not unmindful that the services of a Minister would be most valuable at Cape Mudge, but I do not think the plan which the Church have in mind is workable at Cape Mudge, and furthermore I do not feel a Minister who would have other duties than teaching could possibly do justice to the education of the children. This contemplated change has caused considerable worry to this office, and I wish to be quite frank with the Department in expressing my views and therefore will go into detail in order that the Department will have the situation fully before them.

The Cape Mudge School is considered one of our best Day Schools; the attendance as shown by the Quarterly Returns is exceptionally good, and the Indians appreciate the value of an education and have given the Department fullest co-operation and support in having their children attend school regularly as well as assisting the teacher in every way possible. The size of the school has proven to us the necessity of a full-time teacher who has no other duties to perform, and if the teacher was required to hold three services as well as teach school, I am quite positive the school would suffer to a great extent.

We have a very splendid teacher in Miss Hill, who has given splendid service; she lives with her parents in the teacherage provided by the Department, and to lose her services at this time when she is liked by the Indians and receiving their support would undoubtedly be not in the best interests of the children.

I have been advised the Indians held an indignation meeting some ten days ago and have protested to the Church against the proposed change, giving as their reasons their appreciation of what the Department is doing for them by providing a qualified teacher who is giving her whole time to their education and stating their views along the same lines as indicated and expressed by myself.
I am also informed the Church upon receiving this objection from the Indians, arranged for Dr. Wilson, head of the Church Board, to meet them last night at Cape Mudge to see if he could not persuade them to accept the Church's views but at the time of writing I have not learned the outcome of this meeting.

I understand there is a possibility of the Church suggesting to the Department that they pay a portion of the Minister-Teacher's salary in an effort to persuade the Department to accept their views so that the minister might be located at Cape Mudge to serve Campbell River, Quathiaski Cove and possibly other points in the district. While I am very much interested in economy where it is practical, yet this view does not change my opinion, and I am strongly opposed to any arrangement whereby the teacher employed at Cape Mudge will have other duties than attending to the education of the children.

I would like to refer the Department to Inspector Barry's recent report in connection with this school in which he points out the undesirability of a change being made as suggested by the Church. I know from what knowledge I have from the views of the Indians expressed to me, that a change of this kind will be unacceptable to them and possibly lead to a lot of unpleasantness at Cape Mudge. Both Capt. Barry and myself have strived to raise the standard of our schools by our consistent efforts and personally I feel if this change is made it will be a step backward from what has been accomplished.

While I do not wish to offer any suggestions to the Church in finding a solution to their problem, nevertheless there have been views expressed by a great many ministers that a more satisfactory arrangement could be made which would serve their interests equally as well if not better. If the Church should approach the Department to make the change that is suggested, I trust the Department will be able to convince them it would be a mistake to have an arrangement such as this at this time.

Would the Department kindly take this letter into consideration and advise me their views as we do not wish any trouble arising at Cape Mudge when things are as satisfactory as they are at the present.

Your obedient servant,

(M. S. Todd)
Indian Agent

Sir,

Further to my letter of yesterday's date regarding the situation at Cape Mudge, I have had an opportunity of discussing this matter confidentially with Rev. L. Gillard, United Church minister at Alert Bay, who has just returned from Cape Mudge where he attended the meeting held by Dr. Wilson and the Indians in an effort to persuade the Indians to accept the proposed change of Rev. T. Colwell succeeding Miss Hill as teacher of the Cape Mudge Day School.

As the information imparted to me was more or less confidential, it being purely Church matters, I would appreciate if the Department would treat the Church views as such.

Mr. Gillard told me the Church's intention was purely to get the Department to assist in paying the Minister's salary. They have two plans in mind; the first is to get the Indians to agree to accept Rev. Colwell as teacher and for him to hold service at Cape Mudge only. The second plan is to have Mrs. Colwell appointed as teacher, leaving Mr. Colwell free to attend to the Church matters by holding services at Quathiaski Cove, Campbell River and Cape Mudge, as well as providing him with a boat to serve other outlying districts. They have a boat on the Arrow Lakes which is of no use to them there, and are planning to ship this to Vancouver and send it to Cape Mudge for this purpose.

Mr. Gillard told me confidentially that if Mr. Colwell was appointed as teacher in his opinion it would be a step backward as his teaching qualifications are not as high as those of Miss Hill. He also stated at the present time Mrs. Colwell is teaching in a private school in Vancouver and that her qualifications were satisfactory. He further stated the Indians asked Dr. Wilson at the meeting how she could hope to teach school when she has four or five young children of her own to care for, which to me seems quite logical when Mr. Colwell under these arrangements would be away from home on the boat most of the time.

At this meeting called by Dr. Wilson to interview the Indians only a few of them would turn out, and those who did go stated if the Church insisted on this change being made they would receive very little co-operation from the Indians.

For the Department's information, Mr. Gillard is familiar with local conditions and he told me he knew the plan was not workable nor in the best interests of the Indians, and stated he told the Conference this when he expressed his own views to them recently in Vancouver. He also stated Dr. Wilson told him as well as the Indians that he personally did not approve of it, but that his hands were tied by Rev. Kenneth Beaton in Toronto who is insisting that this arrangement be made.
Mr. Gillard also informed me he and Dr. Wilson visited Mr. Walker, late missionary-teacher of Cape Mudge to get his views, as well as many others in the district who are interested in the welfare of the Indians, and every-one in expressing his opinion said the Church would be making a grave mistake in letting Miss Hill go and making a change as in their opinion it would be a step backward and they would not receive the co-operation of the Indians. They felt this would undo the progress that has been made through the splendid co-operation of the Indians with the Department and the Church in the past.

I understand Dr. Wilson returned to Victoria last evening where a further meeting was to be held by the Board in respect to the suggested change.

Mr. Gillard informed me that unless they could find a position for Miss Hill they would not appoint Mr. Colwell to this position, but they had in mind a position for her at the Coqualeetza Residential School.

This office is very much concerned because we can see through the attitude of the Indians; should a change be made along the lines indicated the work at this school would be retarded and much unpleasantness prevail, and personally I would not care to take the responsibility of anything that would happen through the outcome of such a change.

The Indians in their objection pointed out to Dr. Wilson that a Minister be appointed a school teacher, he would be called upon to hold funeral services when any deaths occurred in the vicinity and that would mean the closing of the school under these circumstances.

As far as I can gather, everyone whom Dr. Wilson consulted who knows local conditions, informed him the suggested change the Church is contemplating is unworkable and would not be in the best interests of the Indians or the district. I am told most of the members of the local Board wished to see a minister located at Cape Mudge, where they have a good manse to serve the entire district; this arrangement would be quite separate from the school. They feel there is a large field to cover which I know is correct, and would require the full-time services of a Minister to carry out this work, but that the Rev. K. Beaton is not in favour of it on the grounds of economy; he is trying to combine the two positions into one with that view in mind.

I would strongly recommend to the Department that they try and convince the Church of the necessity of retaining Miss Hill's services, and would appreciate if they would kindly advise me as quickly as possible their views so that I may notify the Indians and so relieve the tension which has been created at Cape Mudge. When I received this full information from Mr. Gillard I felt it was so serious I communicated with the Department by night letter which doubtless they have received by now.

Your obedient servant,

(M. S. Todd)
Indian Agent

Dear Mr. Sutherland:

I have your letters of June 12th and 20th concerning Cape Mudge, and I have delayed replying until some of the difficulties in the situation could be adjusted.

It is true that the Settlement Committee of the British Columbia Conference have appointed an Ordained Missionary Teacher to the Cape Mudge field, and that they propose to provide him with a boat enabling him to give more efficient service to Campbell River and other nearby points. Most of the objections raised by the Indians are groundless. Rev. T. C. Colwell, B.A., is not only a University graduate, but he holds a Teacher's certificate and has taught in both Ontario and Alberta. His wife is also an experienced Teacher. Her original certificate was obtained in Scotland, and is the highest grade of Teacher's certificate obtainable in Scotland. Having examined it carefully, I think it would be the equivalent of two years in the University of Toronto with one year additional at Normal School; or in other words, it would be what we in Ontario call a First Class Permanent certificate. My hope is that Mrs. Colwell will be nominated as the Teacher, although that was not the intention of the Settlement Committee in B.C. That would ensure not only efficient teaching in the School, but remove the fear which the Indians apparently have rising out of experiences with Missionary Teachers in the past, that the School would be closed when the Missionary receives week-day calls to other points for funerals, etc.

The one unsolved problem up to date is the finding of a place for Miss Jean Hill. I have explained to our representatives in B.C. that Miss Hill was an appointee of Captain Barry, and that it is very important that a School should be secured for her. We have no Indian Day School open in B.C. this year to which she could be appointed, and I am wondering if there is any School where the Department makes the appointment that is likely to be open.
Miss Hill is, as you know, a Saskatchewan trained Teacher, but she has done excellent work at Cape Mudge and is worthy of every consideration.

I expect to be in Ottawa early next week, and to discuss this situation, along with a number of others, with you.

Yours very sincerely,

On the 24th of September, Captain Barry arrived at Alert Bay and inspected the Indian Summer School as well as St. Michael's Residential School. A report by myself to the Department on the Summer School will be made shortly as requested by Major B.M. D.M. MacKay Indian Commissioner.

As the Cape Mudge and Campbell River Day Schools are supposed to open on October 1st, I regret I cannot make any comment on these schools to date I have not been notified that teachers have been appointed. It is hoped the Department will do everything possible to get these particular schools opened as the children are in the villages and ready to attend. In respect to the Quatsino Indian Day School the same situation exists there as I have not been notified of any teacher being appointed; however in this particular school it is not quite so important as the pupils have not all returned to the village as yet.

I am feeling rather upset in respect to Miss Uphill, teacher of the Campbell River School. In her case she was quite willing to remain there provided the Department gave her an increase in salary to cover her increased cost of accommodation, and personally I think she was entitled to it, but instead of giving her the increase, she was permitted to be transferred to the Nanaimo Day School at an increased salary, which resulted in the Campbell River School being left without a teacher and the necessity of breaking in a new one.

Dear Sir,

During the latter part of October, I visited the Cape Mudge Indian Day School and met the new teacher, Mrs. Goodrich. After discussing the work with her and giving her what help I could, I had grave doubts in my mind as to whether she would make a success, and feeling this way I particularly tried to assist her with some of her supposed problems which she presented to me.

On November 24th last I again visited this school, and was immediately told by Mrs. Goodrich that she was leaving the end of this week and asking me if I had received her letter, which had evidently arrived after I had left the office. She seemed very much upset, and in a very nervous condition, so much so that I immediately became worried about her. She has been living alone in the teacherage, and whether this has anything to do with it or not I cannot say, but I am afraid it has. After talking with her I told her that both she and the Department were required to give thirty days notice, and asked her if she could carry on until Christmas. She informed me she would think it over and if I did not hear from her on Wednesday the 26th I would know she was staying until Christmas time. However on Thursday morning I received the following wire: "Leaving Cape Mudge November 29th; letter follows".

Had there been sufficient time to send a wire to stop payment of her last month's salary cheque, I would have done so, but I felt the cheque had already been issued and no doubt mailed from Ottawa.

It might be as well for me to give the Department my views as to what has transpired in Cape Mudge and caused the resignation of this teacher. First, I do not think Mrs. Goodrich felt that she had the ability to teach the higher grades in the classroom, and it became a great worry to her. Secondly, she did not appear to get on with the Indians, and in my opinion she is to blame for this as she refused to have anything to do with the parents; I do not think she likes Indians and always seemed to be looking for trouble. She was not happy in the teacherage, and complained about the building.

The Cape Mudge village, as the Department knows, is one of our best, and to have a problem with the school is working not only to the disadvantage of the village itself but to everything connected with the Cape Mudge people, as they have always been very proud of their Church and the education of their children. That is why I feel more attention should be given to this school possibly than to some others. When Miss Hill was teaching there and living with her parents in the teacherage, it was an ideal arrangement but from the time the Church moved this family out there has been nothing but grief, and I would like to see them come back if at all possible. Miss Hill is a good teacher, is well liked.

Indian Affairs. (RG 10, Volume 6386, File 805-1, part 1)
well liked by the Indians, and her people have a very good influence in the community life of that place. When I received Mrs. Goodrich's wire stating she was leaving the following night, I wired to Miss Hill at Port Simpson asking her if she would consider a transfer back to Cape Mudge, and am this morning in receipt of a message from her stating if this was approved by the Department she would consider a transfer if full transportation costs were paid, as she could not afford to move otherwise.

If this was arranged, and Miss Hill transferred back to Cape Mudge, possibly Miss Marguerite Stevens of Aostak, Manitoba, about whom I wrote you recently, who is United Church, might be given the position at Port Simpson now held by Miss Hill.

I think I should tell the Department also that a great deal of our trouble in Cape Mudge village is on account of the missionaries who have been there during the past few years. The United Church have now there a Reverend and Mrs. McConnell, who have been successively for years; these elderly people mean well, but it is hopeless to have them trying to minister to young people, and the result has been that it is not only making it difficult for the teacher but it is disorganizing and disrupting the whole village life. Mr. and Mrs. Hill have in the past done as much practical missionary work at Cape Mudge as any missionary, and in my opinion if this family would return to the village the resident missionary could be removed and services held intermittently by a transient clergyman, if the Church has no younger men available for these positions.

No doubt the school will now have to be closed until after the Christmas holidays, but I would kindly ask you to take up the matter with Mr. Bunt, Superintendent of Missions for the United Church, and see if some arrangement cannot be made to revivify the Cape Mudge situation and have Miss Hill and her people moved back to this village.

Your obedient servant,

Dear Major MacKay:

I am forwarding herewith my report on the Cape Mudge Indian Day School, United Church of Canada, Kwawkewlth Agency, which I inspected this afternoon.

I am sorry to say that the teacher, Mr. Moyer, has not made a good start here. You will remember that I did all I could for him when he called on me in Vancouver in December. It would not appear that he has put into effect the suggestions then made for his assistance, and I very much doubt that he will ever make a teacher. He lacks professional training and is in fact the second teacher here this academic year.

Mr. Moyer has not gained any marked degree of control of his pupils. The failure in discipline is due to the teacher and not to the children, who are very easy to handle. I would ask you to refer to my last report on this school dated March 11th, 1941, following my visit to the school the preceding day.

The school was found to be in a most untidy condition, papers and orange peel all around the building and bits of paper all over the schoolroom floor.

Mr. Moyer's appointment was I believe of a temporary nature, and I would recommend that his services be not continued after the close of the present academic year in June, 1942. He is I believe a well meaning young man but he is not suited to be a teacher and should seek other work in my opinion.

Yours very truly,

(Sgd.) Gerald H. Barry,
Inspector of Indian Schools, B.C.

Dear Mr. Todd:

The closing of Indian Day Schools one week later than the Provincial Schools, has brought to the fore a question that has been in my mind for sometime. Since we follow the same course of studies as the Provincial Schools, would it not be better for us to follow the same dates of opening and closing school?

I have found that whenever we re-open a few days earlier or close a few days later than the other schools, there is a very strong feeling of resentment among the pupils and in some cases among their parents too. I fully appreciate the fact that the department wishes the children to attend school as many days as possible during the year; but the children, and some of their parents, seem to feel that it is a matter of discrimination against them simply because they are Indian children. This is particularly the case, when, as at Cape Mudge, there are a number of Provincial School in the same district.

Would it be possible for you to take this matter up with the department, because, in my opinion, opening and closing school on different dates from the Provincial Schools has a detrimental effect upon our work.

Yours truly,

(signed) Margaret Wilson.

It is regrettable the time has now come when I must make an adverse report against the activities of the Rev. T.T. Moore, United Church Minister, located at Cape Mudge Reserve.

During the few years Mr. Moore has been Minister at Cape Mudge Village he has made himself very disagreeable towards our teachers; so much so that we have been unable to keep good teachers for any length of time. He has quarrelled and made their lives so unhappy that some of them have resigned without completing their term.

This year the Rev. W.P. Bunt, Superintendent of Home Missions, United Church of Canada, recommended that Mrs. B.M. Kitchenmaster be transferred from Kitsegukla to Cape Mudge School. Upon her arrival Mr. Moore evidently started to quarrel with her. This was before school opened. On August 29th Mrs. Kitchenmaster wired me her resignation. I immediately put in a long distance phone call, which incidently cost the Department $7.85, to try and persuade her to remain there and open the school, pointing out that we could not obtain another teacher. This she finally agreed to do with the understanding that the Department take the matter of his interference up with the Church Authorities.

I enclose you, herewith, copy of a letter I have just received from Mrs. Kitchenmaster, which will be self-explanatory, and which was written prior to her wire of resignation. A serious quarrel evidently took place after this letter was written which forced her to resign.

For years I have been trying to deal with this problem believing it might be of a local petty nature, but am now convinced that it is a deliberate attempt on the part of Rev. Moore to interfere with the duties of the teacher. Mr. Moore has the idea that the teachers have to take orders from him and that the Department have no say in the administration of Day Schools. I have pointed out to Mr. Moore on many occasions that the administration of the Schools comes entirely within the jurisdiction of the Department, and have tried to get him to see that his duties there are purely ministerial and that the administration of the school is the responsibility of the Department; but he evidently thinks otherwise and insists on ordering the teacher around as he sees fit.

I think the kindest thing to say is that the situation has become hopeless and through his activities the efficiency of this school is deteriorating. This is one of the best attended schools we have and I should like to see it running smoothly and the children able to have the benefit of a good education, but this cannot be done when the administration of the school is being interfered with unnecessarily by the local minister continually quarrelling with the teachers.

I am asking that the Department take this whole matter up with the Rev. Bunt with a view to cleaning up this situation for once and all. There is no object in allowing it to go on, and so far as I can see there is no hope of it improving so long as Mr. Moore remains at Cape Mudge.

Dear Mr. Todd:

I am still here and I will remain until the end of the month if possible to see what happens. Dr. Reddan has advised me that this man's case has been pending for sometime and will be dealt with as soon as Rev. Bunt returns from Montreal.

He has acquired a very peculiar attitude toward everything and everybody. If I speak well of anyone, it is just too bad for me. If I take an optimistic view of anything, he sees no good.

We have had an open clash. I told him a few things very plain. He certainly is living very wrong in his thought world. Certainly we cannot both remain in this small village and if it is for me to go, I will do so at the end of the month. One could not possibly cooperate with a man like him. I sometimes wonder if he is just responsible for what he says.

The stoves here are not up to much. The range in the kitchen is hopeless. I have been wondering if the chimney has something to do with it. I bought new pipes for the stove in the front room as the pipes were badly rusted and I was afraid of fire. I was fortunate in being able to purchase a two burner Coleman gas stove at the B. C. Packers to cook on. I bought a cord of wood but I would be so pleased if you bought me an oil burner.

This is a lovely little spot. The yard can be made very pretty and the cottage has possibilities. The children and I will clean the school yard next week. The ladies of the village scrubbed and cleaned the windows in the school the night before we opened.

Dear Mr. Tedd:

Your letter with regard to trouble with the teacher has come to hand and I should like to assure you that it is not my desire or intention to interfere with her work in any way whatsoever. However I am not at all responsible for opinions and notions that she may have from time to time. Up to the date of your letter to me I have had little time to see her at all let alone bother her in any way. Peter Kelly was here for her first four days and then I was away in Vancouver and only returned for Dr. Le-Violette's visit. During the time of his visit we were very occupied. After that I went away until two days ago for Scout Camp.

I think that if you look into the matter you will find that there are some other causes at the root of her disturbances. Probably the main external cause is the fact that she has not got the authority over the people here that she had up north and also that they cannot be bullied in the same way. Her statement that she had an Agent removed up north failed to impress them at all here, for example.

One point that may have been the source of irritation which ---- expression against me by her was the fact that Jean Hill payed us a short visit during the vacation and was joyfully received in the village. Naturally her visit was purely social and if she read anything into it you yourself should know how little there would be to that.

Dear Mr. Todd:

I am still here and I will remain until the end of the month if possible to see what happens. Dr. Reddan has advised me that this man's case has been pending for sometime and will be dealt with as soon as Rev. Bunt returns from Montreal.

He has acquired a very peculiar attitude toward everything and everybody. If I speak well of anyone, it is just too bad for me. If I take an optimistic view of anything, he sees no good.

We have had an open clash. I told him a few things very plain. He certainly is living very wrong in his thought world. Certainly we cannot both remain in this small village and if it is for me to go, I will do so at the end of the month. One could not possibly co-operate with a man like him. I sometimes wonder if he is just responsible for what he says.

The stoves here are not up to much. The range in the kitchen is hopeless. I have been wondering if the chimney has something to do with it. I bought new pipes for the stove in the front room as the pipes were badly rusted and I was afraid of fire. I was fortunate in being able to purchase a two burner Coleman gas stove at the B. C. Packers to cook on. I bought a cord of wood but I would be so pleased if you bought me an oil burner.

This is a lovely little spot. The yard can be made very pretty and the cottage has possibilities. The children and I will clean the school yard next week. The ladies of the village scrubbed and cleaned the windows in the school the night before we opened.

Your letter of the 18th inst. with reference to alleged interference with the teacher, Mrs. Kitchenmaster at Cape Mudge Indian Day School, by the United Church Minister, Mr. T.T. Moore, is acknowledged. I enclose a further letter dated the 18th inst. received from Mr. Todd.

It was fully expected that Mrs. Kitchenmaster's arrival at Cape Mudge as teacher would be followed by complaints, although it was thought that it would more likely involve the Indian Agent than the Missionary.

As you are aware, Mrs. Kitchenmaster was appointed as teacher at Kitsegukla Indian Day School in the Babine Agency by your letter of July 12, 1945 (file 151-15-1) on the recommendation of the United Church Board of Home Missions. She was stated to have a Saskatchewan 1st class permanent certificate, several years teaching experience and interested in dramatics and outdoor sports.

Her arrival at this school was followed by a series of complaints by her and she was finally interviewed by Inspector Coleman on January 24th, past, and he reported that he found her most vindictive and unreasonable with very little grounds for complaint, and further that she insisted that she would order supplies when she wished, without authorization, and we would pay the bill, and she would also proceed to Prince Rupert, closing the school, without reference to the Indian Agent or anyone else, and much more along the same lines. The
Inspector found later on this inspection that she had endeavoured to stir up, without success, a revolt against the Department by Miss Brierly, teacher at Glen Vowell, with a view to her making heavy demands on us. There was no evidence of dramatics or playground activities at her school at this time. She is a very stout woman and there is little indication of any physical activity. Apparently she has done very little teaching since her marriage.

The Inspector discussed this teacher with the Reverend Bunt, Superintendent of Home Missions in Vancouver, on his return, expressing the opinion that she was quite unsuitable for our work. However, the Department advised on June 26, 1946 (file 156-8-1) that the Board of Home Missions had recommended her transfer to Cape Mudge School and this had been approved.

We have no details of the dispute between the teacher and the missionary but are aware that relations between the Agent and the missionary were somewhat strained some time ago, although nothing has been heard on the subject lately. Knowing Mrs. Kitchenmaster it is understandable that conflict would arise between her and the Missionary and in referring the Agent's letter of the 5th inst. to Mr. Bunt it was suggested that her statements be accepted with considerable caution.

In view of the Church's nomination of this woman and that her quarrel is with their own Missionary I am of the opinion it is a matter that should be dealt with by them. Mrs. Kitchenmaster will continue to be troublesome and I do not think we should go out of our way to retain her services. It is probably only a matter of time before Mr. Tod will be insisting on her removal.

D. M. MacKay,

I have just returned from an inspection trip to the southern part of my Agency and while there inspected the Cape Mudge Indian Day School.

I interviewed Mrs. Kitchenmaster, teacher, whose resignation had previously been forwarded Ottawa, and wish to report that she discontinued teaching on October 18th. However, in view of her conduct and treatment of the children in the school, I am advising the Department that it would not be in our best interests to ever consider employing her at any future date. We are very fortunate that she has resigned. It is regretted the school is now closed, but in my opinion it is better for the school to be closed than carried on under her supervision.

Re: Cape Mudge Indian Day School

Early in the present academic year the Campbell River School Board was approached to secure the admission of the Grade 7 and 8 pupils from the Cape Mudge School to the Provincial School nearby. At the time the Indian school, due to its size, could not accommodate all of the 43 pupils seeking admission. In the hope that the senior pupils would be admitted to the Provincial school the Indian school continued to operate on a regular basis by excluding the senior group. Towards the end of October we were still corresponding with the Provincial authorities. At this time the Indian school teacher made an arrangement with Mr. D.K. Gilchrist, who was visiting the United Church Missionary at that point, to take the grade 7 and 8 pupils in the school for two hours in the afternoon after the regular classes were dismissed so that they would not drop too far behind in their studies. Unfortunately she did not inform this office of her action until December because she hoped that the pupils concerned would soon be admitted to the Provincial school. After carrying on for some time on a voluntary basis Mr. Gilchrist felt that he should receive some remuneration for his services but continued to teach until December 23rd.

It is realized that the Department has no legal responsibility with regard to granting any remuneration to Mr. Gilchrist. It is felt however that the circumstances warrant the payment of one month's salary at the classification of teacher, Grade 1 for his two months half-time service at the above mentioned school.

W.S. Arneil
Indian Commissioner for B.C.

Dear Sir,

I have forwarded my school returns to Alert Bay & you will no doubt see them shortly.

I need word some time ago that I was to rec an increase of salary from Apr 1/22 & so far it has not come if this
could also be sent soon
it would be more help
now than later on.
Thanking you in advance

Yours sincerely

OTTAWA, January 4, 1923.

Madam:

In reply to your letter of the 26th ultimo, I beg to say that the Department is forwarding today a cheque for $60.00 in payment of your bonus for the September and December quarters.

Regarding your salary as teacher of the Cape Mudge School, I beg to say that this was increased to $200 per year from September 1, 1922. Your salary was paid at this rate for the September quarter, and a cheque for $225.00 was sent as usual to the Treasurer of the Methodist Missionary Society, Toronto.

Your obedient servant,

Russell T. Ferrier,
Supt. of Indian Education.

Mrs. Florence Howard,
Teacher, Cape Mudge Indian Day School,
Quathiaski Cove, B.C.
Dear Sir,

Replying to Mr. Ferrier's letter of Jan 4th. He notice I need of any increase of salary stated that it would commence with April but I suppose it was a mistake.

Mr. Ferrier states in his letter that a cheque of $200.00 was sent for my Sept quarter salary to the Missionary society. I have need both my Sept & Dec. salary & both cheques were for $200.00 so that up to the present I have not need any increase.

Thanks for bonus check.

Yours sincerely,

Mrs. Florence Howard
Teacher
Cape Mudge.
Ottawa, Jan. 25, 1923.

Madam:

In reply to your letter of the 15th instant I beg to say that as you were previously informed, your salary has been paid at the rate of $900.00 a year from September 1st, 1922. Your cheques have been sent as usual to the Treasurer, Methodist Missionary Society, Toronto, Ont., and you should communicate with him.

Your obedient servant,

[Signature]

Russell T. Ferrier,
Supt. of Indian Education.

Mrs. Florence Howard,
Teacher,
Cape Mudge, Indian Day School,
Kuathiaski Cove, B. C.

Ottawa, February 6th, 1930.

Sir,

I have your letter of the 23rd ultimo, enclosing the December quarter return of the Cape Mudge Indian Day School. In this connection, I have to say that no return has been received for the quarter ended September 30th, last. If this school was open during any part of that quarter, the teacher should prepare a return showing the days taught, enrolment, etc., and forward same as soon as possible in order that payment of the salary due for that period can be made.

Your obedient servant,

Russell T. Ferrier,
Supt. of Indian Education.

W. M. Halliday, Esq.,
Indian Agent,
Alert Bay, B. C.
February 24th,
1930.

The Secretary,
The Department of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa, Ontario.

Dear Sir:

As no cheque for the teacher's salary at Cape Mudge Indian Day School had come from the Department for the September quarter, 1929, I wrote to the teacher - Mrs. Florence Howard - for an explanation and have today received from her the following statement:

"There was no school during September on account of quarantine for measles. All the children who were in the village at the time were sick and the other families stayed away until danger or contagion was over. I was here as usual ready to open school, but could not do so, but, of course, was busy in other ways. I notified the Agent of this."

Perhaps the Indian Agent did not notify the Department of the reason for the absence of school returns for September. I would respectfully ask that, under the peculiar circumstances of the case, and on confirmation of the above statement by the Indian Agent, the usual cheque be forwarded for the teacher's salary for September last.

Yours faithfully,

JNS.MLT

Dear Doctor Dorey:

I desire to refer to your letter of December 6, 1941, nominating Mr. H. G. Moyer as temporary teacher at the Cape Mudge Indian Day School. As you are aware, due to unavoidable circumstances this school was only open for part of the current academic year and consequently I am anxious to have it in operation for the whole of the next academic year.

Dear Sir:

I enclose herewith a letter which Rev. C. H. Tate Soc'y of the Methodist Conf. and Missionary on the Steamer Glad Tidings has asked me to sign and forward to your Department. I am not familiar with the management of Indian Affairs in B. C. but take it for granted that Mr. Tate who has had long experience has made the request in proper form. The information conveyed in the enclosed letter is correct. A teacher has been sent by the Methodist Missionary Society to Cape Mudge and will be maintained there permanently. I am informed that the Department make a grant for school supplies and also some medicine to be used among the Indians. If these grants could be made immediately we should be greatly obliged.

Should you desire further information I shall be glad to call upon you at any time you may name except during the coming
coming week when I shall be away from home.

Trusting that the whole case will receive the favorable consideration of the Department.

I am,

Yours Respectfully,

(Signed) James H. White

Pres. B. C. Conference

A. W. Vowell Esq.
Indian Sup't. Victoria, B. C.

Dear Sir,

At the last Methodist Conference a Missionary was appointed to the Cape Mudge Indians. Mr. Calloway is now in the field, and would like to open a day school at once, as there are over forty children in the tribe. The Methodist Missionary Society has been asked to make an appropriation for the Missionary's residence, and we would like if at the same time the Department could erect a suitable Schoolhouse, to cost not more than $600.

We met the Indians at their village last week, and they expressed a great desire to become better people, especially the young men of the tribe; and, when we consider their past history, we think this a very opportune time, to make an effort to free them from their thraldom.

We trust this matter will
will receive the favorable consideration of the Department, and that the building will be erected before the winter commences.

(Signed) James H. White
President of the Conference.

(Signed) C. H. Tate

Mr. White for a grant of $600.00 to erect a school-house at Cape Mudge, and requesting me to report on the advisability of considering the grant, and also requesting the number of children of school age in the vicinity.

When it was proposed to erect the building last year, it was intended that the cost should be charged to the general vote of tax for day schools for that year, but the vote was not more than enough to carry on the ordinary expenditure, and I think the same will be the case this year. I would suggest that a supplementary be had to cover this expenditure.

Deputy Minister

With reference to letter from
Sept. Vowell of 28th ult. I beg to
report that Cape Mudge is not
too remote a point for the successful
construction of the proposed school
by a contractor, also the sum $600
is not a sufficient inducement.

I respectfully recommend that
Mr. Vowell be requested to instruct
Agent Pidcock to proceed immediately
with the construction of the proposed
school-building at Cape Mudge.

That the land may be
selected as proposed by Mr. Pidcock.

He will be careful to select
site for the building on the Cape
Mudge Indian Reserve and at a
point that will be convenient and
satisfactory for the attendance of the
children.

Agent Pidcock may exercise
his own discretion in the matter
of the erection of the building, that is
he may let the whole or parts by the job or piece to any individual or individuals whom he may think have reason to believe to be capable and responsible parties or he may have the work done by days labour under an experienced carpenter and with such other assistance as may be required.

In either case Agent Picock must take upon himself the general superintendence of the work and will be held responsible for its economical and careful erection.

Vouchers for each and all expenditures, pay lists and payments for job-work in detail must be forwarded without fail to the Dept.

A cheque for $600.00 I am pleased to be expended in the erection of the school at Rossmere.
to enable Agent Piccock to purchase lumber and other materials and for any necessary preliminary expenses, the balance of $207 will be forwarded on application. Dear Sir:

I enclose herewith Mr. Indian Agent Todd's Requisition of the 20th instant for the re-construction of a fence at Cape Mudge Day School, at a cost of $57.15.

In this connection I would advise that this small Indian Village is, to the writer's knowledge, the most advanced and cleanest that I have had the privilege of inspecting.

Indian houses are fully equipped with most modern bathrooms; kitchens replete with built-in cabinets and fixtures made by the Indians, and the other rooms in the house are being modestly but well furnished and clean. The gardens are fenced and well cared for. In consequence, any dilapidated condition of the Departmental buildings on the Reserve would make rather poor comparison and, under these circumstances, I would recommend approval of the application if funds could be provided.

Indian Commissioner for B. C., Department of Mines
and Resources, Vancouver, B. C.

This is to acknowledge receipt of your circular
letter 215-6571 dated, September 3rd, 1943.

It would appear the department is not aware of
the difficulties experienced in obtaining help on the
coast, and in order that you will understand what we
are up against in this respect, I wish to give you the
following information.

During the past summer holidays it was my intention
to redecorate the following schools: Cape Mudge, Campbell
River and Alert Bay, and money was requested in our estimates
for this purpose. Realizing how difficult it was going
to be to obtain labor for this purpose and also supplies
and materials, I started early in April to try and find
labor that would do this decorating with the result that
up until the end of July I had been unsuccessful. I
finally appealed to the Cape Mudge school teacher's
husband and as a last resort he agreed to do it.

It is not a question, insofar as this office is
concerned, of leaving matters over, but, rather, our
inability to get help. There is no use in ordering material
until such times as we know the labor can be obtained.

It is my intention to try and have the Campbell
River and Alert Bay schools decorated during the Christmas
holidays, as both schools require it, and at that time I
may be able to obtain the services of an Indian who is
temporarily home from the fishing grounds.

(Ms. S. Todd)
c.c. Indian Affairs Branch, Ottawa. Indian Agent.
